name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the impact of the bankruptcy of the Thomas Cook Group (2019/2854(RSP)).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission is deeply concerned by the recent insolvency of Thomas Cook. Tourism is an important economic activity for the European Union. It contributes – directly and indirectly – 10% of EU GDP and employs more than 25 million people. This equals 11% of total EU employment. For some European regions, tourism is even the main economic activity. The tourism sector is also much interlinked with other economic activities. One euro of value added in tourism results in 56 cents’ value added upstream, and in this sector there are not only big players: out of the 2.2 million enterprises active in tourism, 90% are small or medium-sized enterprises. The combination of these factors makes the tourism industry not only complex, but also tightly connected with, and affecting, other areas of the economy. The unfortunate insolvency of Thomas Cook exemplifies this well: it shows once more that tourism and the travel industry require an integrated approach across different European policies. We are in contact with the Member States to assess the impacts in terms of the numbers of businesses, jobs and travellers affected in their constituency, and to share information about the European support available to help address such impacts. European instruments are available under different policy areas and may be mobilised to support Member States.  First, we can help avoid negative impacts on the people affected by job losses. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is a strong demonstration of European solidarity: it provides assistance to dismissed workers to help them find new employment, on top of what public employment services offer. The EGF may be triggered by Member States under certain conditions and the Commission stands ready to help the Member States concerned. Furthermore, the European Social Fund may support actions to help dismissed workers for retraining, reskilling and job counselling.  Second, other cohesion policy instruments may help affected regions. The European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in particular can be instrumental in helping regions that face problems of industrial transition, digitalisation, globalisation, decarbonisation natural disasters or regions that need to diversify – for instance, by avoiding too strong a dependence on the tourism sector. The ERDF support is available via the relevant national and regional managing authorities, in line with the respective operational programmes.  Third, European state—aid rules give Member States flexibility to support companies facing acute liquidity shortages due to unforeseen circumstances. In particular, Member States can create schemes supporting SMEs which face financial difficulties. Any scheme has, of course, to be notified to the Commission and be approved. Fourth, on the question of travellers’ rights, the Directive on package travel obliges organisers such as tour operators to have insolvency protection to ensure the repatriation of travellers to their place of departure and the reimbursement of the travel services not yet performed, free of charge for the affected travellers. Repatriation worked well for all the Thomas Cook travellers.  The Commission is currently evaluating how Member States transposed the Directive on package travel, and its focus is in particular on the effectiveness of the insolvency protection schemes. We will report to the Council and to the European Parliament, of course, by January 2021. Let me also recall our proposed revision of the Passengers’ Rights Regulation – EU Regulation 261/2004. With that revision, we aim at improving the effectiveness and consistent enforcement of passengers’ rights, while better taking into account the financial capacities of the air carriers. This proposal, which is still in the interinstitutional procedure, does not provide for any specific rules in the case of airline insolvencies. With its 2013 Communication on passenger protection in the event of airline insolvency, the Commission proposed a number of soft measures.  It is worth pointing out some tools in place to mitigate the negative impacts of insolvencies on passengers, such as an industry commitment to provide rescue fares to passengers, which was indeed triggered on several occasions. Furthermore, national authorities have, in some cases, been actively engaging in ensuring the repatriation of stranded passengers. However, the Commission is aware of the difficulties passengers may still face in asserting their rights ahead of, or during, insolvency proceedings.  In the light of the recent experiences and mechanisms in place, the Commission is currently examining options and a possible follow-up of the 2013 Commission communication on passengers’ protection in the event of airline insolvency.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, today we have brought to this House, at the initiative of the People's Group, the debate for the House to reflect on the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook, a company that has overcome two world wars, 178 years of history, but has not overcome the adaptation to digitisation, the uncertainties of Brexit and the future of that new world of the 21st century. We have to reflect, because in the end it was a company with 105 aircraft, more than two hundred hotels and more than five hundred agencies located almost all in the UK; 22,000 employees. My region, the Balearic Islands, is one of the regions – with the Canary Islands, Andalusia and Catalonia – most affected by this bankruptcy, not only by the loss of jobs, but also by the number of people, tourists, who stayed in those days on the islands themselves. I would also like to tell you that this bankruptcy brings problems not only in hotels: in the tertiary sector, in the transport sector and throughout the economy in general. It is therefore necessary to ask this Commission, this Parliament to have a serious and in-depth debate and reflection on tourism; a strategy — as the sector asks for — on tourism, truly a European strategy, which helps to be able to take on the challenges of digitisation, which change at the speed of light; we need to make a tourism strategy in a sector that accounts for more than 4% of the European Union's GDP. We also need to reflect on how to prepare the European economy to cushion the decline of large companies and their possible subsequent effects, which are many and diverse. Also on consumer rights. More prevention has been needed in this crisis, but more coordination has also been needed. In the Member States there have been lights and shadows in the management of this bankruptcy; there has been uncoordination, particularly in my autonomous community, the Balearic Islands. But above all, we need to reflect on the protection of certain agents and property when a bankruptcy occurs. I trust Commissioner Thyssen, who has a special sensitivity, to be able to mobilize the funds — European Social Fund, ERDF, European Globalisation Adjustment Fund — and for Europe to shake hands with the Member States in order to alleviate above all the human effects in this important sector which is tourism.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! I would also like to express my solidarity with the affected employees of Thomas Cook and the many passengers who experienced negative consequences in connection with the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook in September. Thomas Cook has for decades been a huge company that has brought a great many travellers across Europe and the world, but is no longer there.  But the bankruptcy also shows us that we are simply not in place in Europe with the rules needed to protect consumers and workers. And we know that there are many companies – both travel companies and airlines – that are going bankrupt on an ongoing basis. Since 2017, 32 airlines have gone bankrupt with our touches here in Europe. We simply do not have good enough legislation in place. And then it's fine, we have funds and everything that can help, it's obviously better than nothing. However, we Socialists want us to tighten up and improve our legislation in this area. We believe that a comprehensive and comprehensive approach is needed for our airlines, our travel companies in Europe. Travelling in Europe must be safe and it must be safe to work in Europe. And it has turned out that this has not been the case for the many who have worked at Thomas Cook and who have used the travel company. That is why we believe that more needs to be done.  On the one hand, our passenger rights for air travellers must be better – the Commissioner mentioned that too, and it is a pity that we have not made any progress on this.  The European Parliament has dealt with the matter and we have our proposal for it. Now we need to get the Council up and running. But we also believe that more is needed than that.  We also need to be able to look at whether we should not go in and help at European level when there are bankruptcies in companies that are so large and affect so many people. So more action is needed than what we have seen at present, so that our consumers and our workers can be more confident when travelling in Europe.

name: José Ramón BAUZÁ DÍAZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, I would like to begin by pointing out to the Commission that today's debate is not about Thomas Cook's bankruptcy, but precisely on how Thomas Cook's bankruptcy has affected thousands of people and certain regions with names and surnames — in the case of Spain: the Balearic Islands, the Canary Islands — as a result of a negligent decision by a company that knew perfectly well , hours before its closure, it was going to go bankrupting.  Just today I want to be the voice of all those thousands of tourists who have put the best of their year's expectations in going on vacation to stay on land or not get home. I want to be the voice of all those consumers who don't yet know if they're going to get their money back today.  I want to be the voice of all those employees who, at night, at night hours—at two in the morning—saw their jobs lose. And since I also know many of them, who are excellent professionals, I know that today many of them continue to work despite not collecting their payrolls, simply because they do not know what is going to happen to them in terms of labor legislation and how they will finally determine their future justice.  And I also want to be the voice of all those drivers and those tour guides who don't know what's going to happen next year with their season.  In short, today the Commission is more important than ever and it is not the time for words, but for facts. In this sense, on behalf of Citizens and on behalf of Renew Europe, the liberal group to which I belong, I would like to tell all of them that we will not leave them alone and that we will go all the way, because precisely those situations cannot occur and concrete action has to be taken.  As a citizen of the Balearic Islands, a community of which I have had the privilege and honor and pride of having been president, I say that I know perfectly and firsthand how to address precisely the development of active public policies to promote tourism.  Ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, now is the time. We cannot pass the time and the future depends exclusively on us.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, while thousands of holidaymakers were grounded and 21 000 staff lost their jobs, a wealthy elite were flying high from the collapse of Thomas Cook. For some hedge fund managers and financial speculators, this was just another business opportunity. Two companies in particular scooped up over GBP 200 million as Thomas Cook went under. These vulture capitalists make rich pickings by investing in financial products that pay out when a company defaults on its debts, as was the case with Thomas Cook. But aside from this perversity of capitalism, we should also consider how Thomas Cook arrived at this destination. The company cited heatwaves and uncertainty over Brexit among the factors in its collapse. So the two biggest issues of our time, the climate emergency and Brexit, played a part. It’s low-cost flights that are fuelling the heating of our planet, which in turn is making popular destinations in Europe unbearable at peak holiday times. Now, tackling climate change will involve new patterns of travel and different types of holiday: overland travel and more stay-cations will have to replace the existing model. And lamenting the loss of jobs in the old system must go hand-in-hand with a properly funded transition to a more secure future. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: blue-card question. – Can I ask Ms Rowett what empirical proof she has that low-cost airlines in particular affect the climate. And my second question to her is: why would you like to deprive the people who can least afford it the opportunity of a cheap holiday with low—cost airlines? (Applause)

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: blue-card answer. – Low-cost airlines don’t adequately measure the effect of aviation on the climate, so it’s low-cost ones that are particularly encouraging more flights than we can afford in this climate crisis. And I’m not proposing that we should have no holidays, I’m proposing that we should have adequate transport that is affordable, and not making the climate fry.

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The reasons for the failure of Thomas Cook – a tour operator that has been established for 178 years – may not yet be clear in detail, but the consequences are. We are talking about 22 000 jobs threatened and for Greece alone we are talking about losses of EUR 250 to 500 million. What we are seeing here is at least the result of a witch-hunt – and we have just seen it here – a witch-hunt, a mood-mongering under the guise of a new Golden Calf in the form of climate protection, which has found its first victim with the tourism industry. More companies, other industries will follow. Of course, I am also thinking of my Bavarian homeland and the car industry there. This has also fallen into the crosshairs of the zeitgeist. I call for us here in the European Parliament not to join this witch-hunt, but for us to do everything in our power to ensure that such cases do not happen again. We must prevent our tour operators from being put in the way, at least from the legislative side, of other obstacles, such as the European Green Deal, and we must recognise that the death of European travel companies is precisely not helping the global climate, but that only competing companies will invade this niche. I would therefore like to conclude by asking you to support our tourism industry at this difficult time – not like the Green colleague here – and to support our motion for a resolution accordingly.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The bankruptcy of the Thomas Cook travel agency is very bad news, not only for hundreds of thousands of tourists, of course, but above all for the entire EU tourism industry, which is very important to the economy. According to preliminary estimates, it will result in a wave of bankruptcy among hotel operators – in Spain, Greece – and the costs of compensing customers will be borne by all countries where Thomas Cook acted directly or indirectly. This is m.in. in my country, Poland, where the consequences of this event were directly felt by several thousand people who had to be brought home in emergency mode.  But I have a question for the Honourable Commissioner. Is this just a one-off case, or is it the beginning of something bigger, the beginning of some kind of crisis in the tourism industry? Is this an individual case, because for some reason the Thomas Cook office was poorly managed, or is there a bigger crisis in the tourism industry in the near future? Is the European Commission looking at this bankruptcy from this side?

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the transport and tourism sector is a strong growth pillar of the European economy. It accounts for 10 % of European GDP and has a catalytic role in the development of many productive sectors. Its importance is vital for regions and island regions that have no other development resources. There is no single mechanism to support local communities and jobs and there is no mechanism to strengthen the image of European tourism that is repeatedly hit, with negative consequences for all.  Europe is a single leading tourist destination and tourism is the fourth largest import sector with a EUR 27 billion surplus. Who will support him, if not the European Union itself? We do not have the means to deal effectively with crises that affect tourism activity in Europe horizontally. We have only one directive on the repatriation of tourists who have purchased travel packages and individual movements of Member States, on the basis of the national interest and without coordination. I want to be clear; the collapse of Thomas Cook is not the only challenge to the sustainability of tourism.  We are faced with the climate crisis and increasing extreme weather events and also with the critical issue of security on issues dominated by the need to respect human rights, such as refugees. We therefore call for the strengthening of legislation to protect travellers against exceptional events, where the same tourist bears no responsibility and it is necessary to draw up a European crisis management mechanism in tourism, for workers, local communities and the image of Europe as a top tourist destination.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I have been a bankruptcy judge in the Republic of Croatia for the past eight years. The items that were in my courtroom weighed several billion euros. In the Republic of Croatia, we have had one huge bankruptcy of a company that can be declared even bigger for the national economy than Thomas Cook.  There is a problem when each state tries to regulate the individual bankruptcy of a company that is a multinational company with its domestic bankruptcy legislation. Then there can be huge problems. We have the business of Agrokor, which was in several countries of the region. We will continue to drag political situations, but the worst that has happened is that we have allowed funds that we do not even know who the owners are to take over the entire property.  Thomas Cook owns, I think, about a hundred planes. That's something to take care of. The European Parliament and the European Union must take into account bankruptcies that are multinational.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I thank you for all that you have explained here in this area which is so dear to us here in the European Parliament.  On several occasions, the Committee on Transport and Tourism in this house has set out the challenges facing this sector. It has set out the need to review a strategy for tourism that is updated, taking into account digitisation, as mentioned here, but which also takes into account climate change and the new challenges that this sector has, with such an important weight for the various Member States of Europe, but for the European destination as a whole. What we are discussing here today in relation to the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook, truly a British tour operator, has to do with the impact it has had on this sector, on tourism, on people who have been stranded in some countries, as was mentioned here in Spain, Portugal, where it affected Madeira and also the Algarve, and we must effectively quantify and see the extent of the effect of this bankruptcy. We need to review how we are going to support small and medium-sized enterprises linked to the sector, how we will support consumers in the rights of passengers who have faced serious situations in the face of these bankruptcy scenarios and how we will cooperate with this very important sector.  Losing air capacity clearly calls into question several European destinations and we must be aware of all these circumstances.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Let me begin by lamenting the bankruptcy of the travel company Thomas Cook. The bankruptcy left more than 22 000 workers without a job to go to. In addition, it left 600,000 people stranded on or on their way to their destinations. In this context, I would like to call on the Member States in the European Council to adopt a position on air passengers' rights as a matter of urgency. Parliament has been ready since 2014 and it is high time that the Council did.  Now it was many times thanks to the employees – who stayed behind and worked without compensation – that the individual travellers came home. That is totally unacceptable. These are the same workers who are now living in uncertainty for their future earnings and their earned pension rights. The rights of these workers must now be protected. The Member States must engage in close dialogue with the trade unions in order to guarantee the rights of these workers, and the European Globalisation Fund must be activated. It should not be the passengers and the workers who suffer from this bankruptcy.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook affects the whole of Europe, and it left more than half a million European citizens stuck in various countries in Europe. This shows the importance of insolvency protection and of guaranteed cover of refunds and reparations if organisers go bankrupt. Neckermann, as Thomas Cook is known in my country, managed to take Czech citizens home immediately, and covered refunds from their insurance protection without taking money from the guarantee fund. They will also provide holidays for those customers who had already paid for their trips. This should be seen as an example of how to handle the situation of bankruptcy without harming the citizens, and minimising their losses. As we have heard today, this is far from being the case everywhere in Europe, and there will be cases where the guarantee funds established by the Package Travel Directive are needed. The important thing is to take care of all EU citizens affected by the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook and its subsidiaries. This situation proves that the Package Travel Directive is working – but maybe we can do better. In two years’ time, the directive will be up for revision. I hope we can learn from this occasion and see where further improvements should be introduced.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Unfortunately, the 2015 Package Travel Directive cannot prevent the damage caused to consumers and contractors as a result of the insolvency of the travel provider Thomas Cook. The problem is insufficient insurance cover. Apparently, nothing has been learned from the insolvency of the travel provider Arcandor in 2009, where a similar situation had arisen. Large tourism providers in particular must be obliged to provide a realistic insurance cover, I stress. I therefore propose an evaluation of the implementation of the Package Travel Directive in the Member States. Improvements to the directive will then be derived in order to increase consumer confidence in the tourism sector in the future.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, someone could look at this aspect of our plenary session. It’s necessary to have action and reaction and I think that, under our rules, it is possible to ask a colleague a question. If someone is speaking about some proposal that he could change, you can ask him how he could change it. I think, in future, it will be much better if you respect this provision. I might be on my political group’s speaking list five times, but this is about the possibility, under the rules, of asking a question of a colleague. Thank you for respecting it.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleague, I think you are completely right that it’s our duty to make this plenary a living example of our debates, and we need debate. But this is actually a new idea, so let me communicate it to the President and to my colleagues in the Bureau so that we can see if that can be done. Thank you very much for your understanding and for your inspiration.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: Mr President, the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook has shaken the whole of Europe a little bit. There is now a acquirer and we all hope for a solid, innovative restart. But I would like to take a look at this incident from a different angle than has happened so far, and that is the following: we in Europe clearly have a productivity problem. Productivity growth has been declining for years and has now become virtually zero. This has very important consequences in terms of job growth, economic growth and public finances. More and more research shows that there is a link between lower interest rates and the fall in productivity; keeping companies alive that accumulate debt and get into immediate trouble with a slightly higher interest rate. Thomas Cook is clearly one of them. I think it is high time that we started to reflect on this low interest rate policy from this perspective.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, almost a month after Thomas Cook declared bankruptcy, the large German, French, British groups, with subsidies, privileges, tax exemptions, are being forced, by vehicle, the subsidiaries of the bankrupt group, over who will reap the benefits of the clientele, the assets, and even the Thomas Cook slots at British airports. At the same time, however, the employees of both Thomas Cook and its partner companies in Greece, with salaries and exhausting hours without days off, took the season off, and today they continue to be literally on the air, without any substantial support from the Greek government and the European Union. It is confirmed that the growth path that serves the profits of the groups is multiple detrimental to the workers, the self-employed, the people who, even on their holidays, pay the marble. We now demand that the full employment and insurance rights of workers who suffer the consequences be guaranteed immediately and without conditions, with full compensation to those affected.

name: Pablo ARIAS ECHEVERRÍA
text: – Madam President, 600 000 affected consumers, 22,000 direct jobs destroyed and hundreds of thousands of indirect jobs harmed. Thomas Cook recorded in May losses valued at 1.5 billion pounds (about 1.68 billion euros), corresponding to only the first half of this fiscal year.  With this resolution from the PPE Group, we want to show that the European Union still does not have a clear voice on tourism, something we have been repeatedly calling for for some time. We need a frank debate with the Commission on this sector so important to the economy and employment of the European Union, which accounts for 4% of our GDP and 5% of direct employment.  The Thomas Cook case also highlights the need to strengthen consumer rights in the event of bankruptcy. Citizens who have bought their plane tickets at Thomas Cook are unprotected, and this is a reality we must face. The European Parliament raised this at first reading in the amendment to Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 on the rights of passengers in air transport. This procedure has been blocked in the Council for four years. Some Member States have used various arguments as an excuse not to move forward with this Regulation. Let's stop making excuses. It's time to act. Let us take advantage of this disaster as an opportunity to raise a broad debate that addresses consumer protection and thus expedites competition procedures for compensation.  With this resolution we propose that the Commission take the issue seriously once and for all, which highlights the weakness of consumers and SMEs in the face of bankruptcies that could have been avoided or at least minimized.

name: Adriana MALDONADO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, as we have been talking about in this debate, on 23 September we were aware of the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook, an essential British tour operator in the tourism sector, a key sector for a country like Spain, my country.  It is true that many tourists and many hoteliers have been affected, but I want to focus on consumers.  From the European Union we must ensure the right of citizens to be backed up with guarantees when shopping for travel on tour operators. The European Commission must therefore be aware — and the Council — that we must learn from this bankruptcy; we have to learn so that it doesn't happen again in the future. In addition, we must also ensure — and the European Commission has to do this - that all possible tools are made available to provide solutions to affected consumers, through Directive (EU) 2015/2302, which is already operational.  It is important that we do this work so that we see that consumers are a key driver for the European Union and for the next European Commission.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Thomas Cook crisis is a new opportunity to show Europeans, and particularly the British, the advantages of membership of the Union. We have robust and comprehensive legislation to guarantee the rights of passengers and tourist customers. All its virtues must be activated to compensate the 600,000 affected and prevent the effects that this bankruptcy can have on areas such as the Canary Islands or the Balearic Islands, which already had the positive impact of hundreds of thousands of reserves, now in the air.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund must also be activated to recycle affected workers for rapid relocation and to support those who, among them, decide to undertake in a sector they dominate and to which they can provide digitisation and personalized offers. European tourist attraction has an opportunity in that knowledge.  Finally, self-criticism must be done, because this "chronicle of an announced death" caught those in charge of the sector lying about the health of the sick. Finally, I hope that I will enlighten the Brexiters about how much those who are committed to moving away from the European security and guarantee framework have lied to them.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Colleagues, I have to point out that we have had several speakers who speak too fast for the interpreters. I don’t know if it’s a pattern, but very often I’ve had to give this reminder to Spanish colleagues from the Spanish language. Maybe there’s something about your way of putting a lot of information into a very short sequence.

name: Julie LECHANTEUX
text: Madam President, the bankruptcy of global giant Thomas Cook on 23 September has created a real tsunami in the global tourism industry.  In France, the fate of 780 employees is suspended by an uncertain takeover offer. Everyone talks, of course, about the burden of this company on the tourism market or the uncertainties associated with Brexit. But what no one is talking about is that the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook was desired by hedge funds. Yes, pension funds and insurers have sold Thomas Cook's debt problem to hedge funds that have insured themselves against a default by that company.  But, according to the professor of economics, Frédéric Vrins, there is even more serious. I quote: "A company could therefore go bankrupt simply because a credit default swap holder is taking legal action to overturn the bailout."  The Thomas Cook case is therefore a new international financial scandal. That is why we have to deal with this financial system that has gone completely crazy and fight it with determination.  Once again, once too many, hundreds of families will be sacrificed because of these vulture funds whose sole purpose is the lure of profit.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The world's oldest tourist office has collapsed, and we know that tourism services and the tourist market are growing. There are many reasons for this dramatic event. We all know that travel companies should carry out their missions fairly, not just think about their own income at the expense of consumers. My great surprise is the situation in which the management of a travel company makes cosmic profits, knowing that the situation of the company at the head of which it is deteriorating – this is the first and most important dishonesty in the economic industry, in tourism. Tourism is one of the branches of the economy that has a very large impact on GDP, has a large impact on the regions. I come from such a region, i.e. from Podkarpacie in Poland, where there are many tour operators, many tourist destinations. I ask you, all the more so we should analyse tourist offers, tourist products from the point of view of their true reliability. The sad end of thomas cook's oldest travel company is a sad opportunity to draw attention to all tour operators and to the fact that we in the European Parliament need an ex ante analysis of all tourist products and travel companies.

name: David BULL
text: – Madam President, British people work extremely hard to put a roof over their heads and to provide for their families’ security. An annual holiday is something that everybody looks forward to and saves for all year. Therefore, I am incredibly sympathetic to those people whose holidays were ruined by the collapse of Thomas Cook. It was a huge operation, employing 22 000 staff, with 19 million customers. But it collapsed because it didn’t innovate and it was underpinned by poor management. It rewarded failure by paying the then-chief executive and directors millions of pounds in pay and bonuses, and 150 000 holidaymakers were stranded around the world, forcing the UK taxpayer to pick up that bill of repatriation costing GBP 100 million. The bigger question is: why are we talking about it here in the EU Parliament? Isn’t this just more EU meddling? This is mission-creep, because if the EU thinks it should be involved then it shouldn’t just be the UK taxpayer picking up the bill. Perhaps the EU would like to put its money where its mouth is, and perhaps the EU would like to cough up some hard cash to compensate.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Commissioner, beyond the collapse of a myth called Thomas Cook, we have of course seen consequences in many countries in terms of employment, in particular. In my country alone, in Belgium, no less than 500 people were affected. So there are consequences for travellers, but also for workers. So we need to work quickly, in the short, medium and long term.  Firstly, of course, and you have pointed out, Commissioner, it is important that all financial means and instruments are used in a flexible, efficient but also rapid way in managing the consequences of this bankruptcy, particularly at the level of European means through, whether it be structural funds, such as the European Social Fund, but also the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. We need to act quickly because families are waiting for answers for their jobs, for their training, certainly, but also simply for their future.  Secondly, I think it is important that the social partners, and in particular the representatives of the workers concerned, play an essential role, both at national and European level - of course, at national level, according to national rules, particularly in managing the consequences of this bankruptcy, of course, but also more broadly. In the future, European social partners in the tourism sector must be permanently and structuredly involved in the development of new rules to deal with such events. And last but not, perhaps, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that we need a much stronger European competence in tourism. The stakes are enormous: this sector has an impact for many Member States, for many people, for many families, for employment, for the development and development of the territories. In the future, therefore, a real European tourism policy with its own budget lines is needed.

name: Alicia HOMS GINEL
text: – Madam President, the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook has had very severe consequences for the tourism sector throughout Europe. For this very reason, I welcome Parliament's consideration of a motion for a resolution which not only reflects the concern of the many affected by thomas Cook's collapse, but also encourages the Commission to act coherently and quickly in future similar situations, as the Government of my region, the Balearic Islands, has done in a coordinated manner — not as Mrs Beres has said — with the Government of Spain.  However, we must also focus on those who have been one of the main affected: the workers in the sector. In a bankruptcy like Thomas Cook's, workers tend to be the most vulnerable, because they are the ones affected with the least maneuverability.  A worker depends entirely on his salary and if he is fired for the bankruptcy of his company or his contract this year is shortened by the advance of the end of the season, the consequence can be dramatic, such as that he cannot reach the end of the month.  The text of the Resolution should take into account the vulnerability of workers with the aim of strengthening their mechanisms of participation in process management as a bankruptcy. Only with greater bargaining power will we ensure that workers have fairer conditions and greater financial security.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Thomas Cook's bankruptcy is of course the result of mismanagement, poorly controlled external growth, but above all the impossibility of leaving for the digital economy properly for a service company, and moreover, at a time when customers are changing their habits and now carrying out direct consultations, dry flights , to dry services in terms of hotels and leisure. So there is a transformation of the digital economy behind this bankruptcy that we should be looking at.  It must be said that a deficit of 300 million cash, which probably results in more than 10 billion indirect damage, still questions the capacity that one would have to take pension measures.  Finally, for an economic sector enshrined in the Treaties which accounts for 10% of the Union's gross domestic product, which is an essential structuring of many fragile peripheral regions, can we admit that it has no budget, no budget line in the Union and that it is permanently the poor relative of our parliamentary work?

name: John David Edward TENNANT
text: – Madam President, founded in 1841, the world’s oldest travel agent, Thomas Cook, was once a great British success story. But like many out of touch businesses, it went into a tailspin as customers migrated to the Internet. Yet what was truly grotesque was that its overpaid directors, who paid themselves GBP 47 million in bonuses over the last 10 years, attempted to put their own ineptitude on Brexit uncertainty. This anti-Brexit propaganda was duly lapped up by our pro-remain media and politicians. We shouldn’t be surprised. Economically illiterate, pro-EU politicians in the Labour party suggested that the British Government should have bailed out Thomas Cook, completely failing to realise that even if MPs had wanted to, EU competition law would have prohibited such an intervention. Their beloved EU is part of the problem, not part of the solution. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: the question asked by raising the blue card. – Can you please explain to half a billion European citizens how the European Commission or the European Union is to do with the collapse of Thomas Cook?  Can you tell how we, as the European Union, have warned your citizens against going to Egypt or other destinations where citizens from all over the European Union go? But it was your government that warned about these destinations. Don't you think the European Union is also to do with the fact that you have a spot on your tie after lunch today? Thank you for your reply.

name: John David Edward TENNANT
text: blue-card answer. – I think it needs to be made fundamentally clear: I have said that even if the British Government or the British Parliament wanted to bail out Thomas Cook, it would not have been able to do so under EU state—aid legislation. That was my point. I think what you’re trying to do is turn this around into some kind of anti-‘us’ effort. I think you need to understand that your own legislation would not have been able to save Thomas Cook.

name: Jörgen WARBORN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Action is now needed to strengthen the business environment in europe, especially in the tourism and transport sectors. There are 12 million Europeans working in the tourism sector and among young people it accounts for one in five jobs. Bankruptcies for the big companies, such as Thomas Cook, send surges to the smaller companies such as taxi companies, hotels and restaurants. Small businesses are the most vulnerable companies, even if it is in the big companies that the problems begin.  The European Parliament must now focus on improving Europe's competitiveness. The business environment must be much better than it is today, especially among small businesses. We need to invest in important infrastructure that binds Europe together. We need to reduce the administrative burden on businesses and we need to ensure that the internal market is fully integrated.  It is up to us – here in the European Parliament, but also and above all in the Commission – to work hard for the work that is now needed. The bankruptcy of Thomas Cook is just a symptom of a very profound problem for Europe's competitiveness. I hope that more people will join me and put business issues at the top of the political agenda. We can't just wait for better times. The work must begin now.

name: István UJHELYI
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support We're talking about the bankruptcy of a major company. But the same situation can occur in the event of a natural disaster, there may be new acts of terrorism. European tourism provides jobs for 27 million people. It is one of our most important sectors and one of the most vulnerable to various disasters.  I ask whether the European Commission and the European Council are sufficiently partners in tresathing tourism problems at European level.  In 1950 there were only 25 million tourists worldwide. Now, last year, in 2018 alone, 710 million international tourists arrived in Europe. This shows that the industry has become global, and we need much more serious EU rules.  I ask why the future President of the European Commission, in the first 100 pages of her paper, has not been able to even mention the word tourism as an industry as an important factor in our daily lives. This case now highlights the need for a much stronger tourism policy at European level. Thank you for your attention.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, I am standing here because my German colleague is stranded on the train. Unlike the thousands of tourists stranded by Thomas Cook's bankruptcy last summer, my colleague does have a backup. Namely, myself.  That is why we must ensure that in the event of a subsequent bankruptcy, the traveller is better informed, but also more quickly, about the consequences. More quickly clarity about where they are and what is or is not insured. So that holidaymakers can come home very quickly in an emergency. I therefore call for stronger national guarantee systems to ensure that no one, especially in the upcoming Christmas holidays, should be left at their destination.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, I think this debate itself is interesting. To see British colleagues shouting that this is their business is really funny. After all, people from all over the world flew with the Thomas Cook office. After all, the fact that this largest travel agency, which has existed since 1841, has gone bankrupt will affect other countries of the European Union and its citizens. It's not just those who have travelled, that is, consumers who have bought a trip from the UK. But it is consumers from other countries, but they are also accommodated in Greece, Italy, Spain, Portugal, who have not been paid to this day. That is why this question needs to be opened up.  Here we need to tell our colleagues in the UK what a mistake they made when they actually voted for Brexit. We have the tools here to solve this problem. Those who are made redundant can apply for money from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, and we have other tools to bring consumers back to the UK.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Commissioner, many things have been said. Debating. It is good that we are debating bankruptcy, a resounding bankruptcy, a company that has over 170 years, with millions of customers, with hundreds of thousands of employees. Do you think it is appropriate, however, to think, the European Commission, to have this segment - tourism - which brings a consistent percentage to the GDP of the European Union, to have a strategy, to have a budget line, to have directions of action, because yes, it is a private company.  I wonder: are you going to analyze why this bankruptcy was? Did this company audit it? Did he have cover insurance? We cannot leave citizens, employees, but also tourists and passengers totally discovered because a company is growing erratically. I can't believe he couldn't see a billion-and-a-billion pound debt when he's been operating for so long, when he has huge turnovers. So here, Commissioner, I'm asking for a very profound analysis. Of course, we have to help passengers, we have to help employees, the Member States have to intervene, but we cannot leave this mess that happened with a company of tradition, the second largest company in the world on tourism.

name: Caroline VOADEN
text: – Madam President, the collapse of Thomas Cook will go down as one of the economic tragedies of our time. The loss of 21 000 jobs will mean hundreds of thousands will suffer across Europe in related jobs, and the families of those employed. The damage to the material and mental well-being of Thomas Cook employees and contractors and their dependants is huge. But we need to offer more than sympathy and nice words. They will not pay the rent for those who have lost their jobs. We need to offer support and training for those workers facing unemployment. We need to offer support and help to those who could create jobs and new businesses to replace those that have been lost. We also need to legislate so that no company can collapse from one day to the next, stranding people all over the world and causing huge distress. We must finish the digital single market and ensure that no European business is faced with the scenario where they have no incentive to digitise. The tourism industry is changing. In my constituency in Cornwall, it employs one in five people. But cheap flights, online booking and Airbnb are all challenging traditional companies. We must ensure we create the right environment to support this changing industry while protecting the beautiful destinations of Europe from ruin, threatened by mass tourism.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Madam President, as a representative of a country where tourism occupies a huge part of gross product and employment, I am naturally concerned and support all measures to support, especially small and medium-sized businesses, family and local tourism businesses. However, I believe that several aspects of the problem are seriously underestimated, including by the Commission. First of all, don't we think there is a dangerous overconcentration of market share in this case, which creates a company too big to perish. "too big to fail"? Do we not believe that there is a dangerous vertical concentration of tourist services that violates the Competition Rules of the European Union? Do we not believe, not least, that in this case it is a model of tourist concentration of services both horizontally and vertically, which, in addition to endangering all consumers, seriously harms small businesses, family businesses, local businesses, a model doomed to bankruptcy?

name: Marianne VIND
text: Madam President! The collapse of Thomas Cook is one thing. Georgia Browning put on her uniform and sat down at the local pub with her colleague to help the stranded tourists. They weren't paid, but they wouldn't let the travelers down. They have been in a good workplace, a good workplace which overnight ended completely without warning. The collapse is unique in size, but not in shape. As so many times before, the big losers are europe's workers. Ceo Fankhauser can, of course, confidently sit back with his million-dollar bonuses. At the same time, thousands have lost their jobs, their families' safety and are now struggling to pay their bills. Management knew there was a danger. Georgia and her colleagues didn't. The whole of Europe should learn from the collapse of Thomas Cook. The social dialogue between management and employees of Europe's large companies must and must be strengthened so that no one is left behind as we see it now.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Madam President, consumer confidence in the Single Market is decisive and can only be achieved with strong protection of their rights.  The tourism sector is of great importance for the European internal market as an engine of economic growth and job creation. The bankruptcy of operator Thomas Cook has a strong impact not only on consumers, but also on affected tourist regions, such as the Algarve and alentejo. This puts at serious risk families, businesses and the local economy.  I believe it is vital that the European Commission and the Member States ensure that the existing rules are applied and the available funds used, and that additional measures, such as strengthening the protection of air passengers, are considered so that consumers are properly compensated for the damage caused.  Only in this way will it be possible to ensure the proper functioning of the internal market and the level of consumer protection to which we are being proposed.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, when Thomas Cook, a British icon, declared bankruptcy in September, hundreds of thousands were left stranded and the 21 000 employees, including 9 000 in the UK, were left unemployed. But let’s not be in any doubt: Thomas Cook went under because of bad management. While the Civil Aviation Authority should be commended for its efforts – thanks to EU passenger rights – to get people home, our Government, unlike others in Europe, did nothing to protect consumers, workers or taxpayers. They sat back and let the company fold: not because they couldn’t do anything, as we’ve heard from the people who have left the Chamber now, but because they did not want to. It was great news that a real corporate success story in tourism – Sunderland’s own Hays Travel – stepped in, saving scores of local jobs as a result. But now, considering the scale of damage to our economy, and particularly our manufacturing industries, as Johnson’s Brexit beckons, we need a government that is willing to defend jobs and rights, not one that sits back and lets those jobs go and then starts to blame others, as we’ve heard here hall tonight.

name: Sara SKYTTEDAL
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The bankruptcy of Tomas Cook is hitting jobs on our continent hard. Unfortunately, we run the risk of seeing further blows to the tourism industry if we do not dare to combat the negative natures of the climate debate. In a report produced by UBS, they warned of the risks of so-called air shame. They found that widespread air traffic pollution could halve growth in air traffic in the EU, with fewer jobs in the tourism sector and a hefty negative impact on the European economy, while only having a marginal impact on the climate.  Flying has become much more environmentally friendly over time. This is a development that is also expected to continue thanks to extensive technological development. If we are serious about ensuring good conditions for the tourism industry, we must also question ideas such as air shame and instead take our responsibility for reducing emissions by paving the way for a new green technology in the aviation industry. That is how we take responsibility for the climate while protecting jobs and growth.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, tourism is one of the largest sectors of the European economy and is a key sector in global tourism powers, such as Spain. Thomas Cook's bankruptcy has caused a crisis that has affected many sectors, services and professions, especially in island regions, where accessibility and connectivity are crucial. The impact at European level has been enormous.  The loss of connectivity and multiple jobs reaffirms that Member States face common challenges, also in tourism, and highlights the need to develop a common European strategy for tourism and to establish prevention and management mechanisms to protect workers, boost our businesses and ensure passenger safety.  We therefore call on the Commission to take into account Parliament's proposal to establish a single budget line for sustainable tourism, to revise legislation to define workers' rights in the event of insolvency of the undertaking. And we look forward to the announced aviation social package. Only in this way can we take the first steps in this common European strategy for tourism.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. If the world's second-largest tour operator goes bust, it will have a huge impact – both on the workers affected and on the many thousands of customers.  I have heard a lot of criticism of the package travel directive here today in the debate, but I believe that this is the wrong addressee. Thanks to the Package Travel Directive, we have regulations at European level in the first place, but these rules in the Member States would then have to be looked at in detail. We have countries like the United Kingdom where, in the end, all the taxpayers have to pay. We have countries like my country, Germany, where there is an insurance solution, but which is not enough in the end – 110 million is not enough for this case. Almost three times the damage has been done, and that is why I call on the Commission – and Mrs Thyssen, as you have fortunately already said in your opening statement – to look again at the directive, but above all at its implementation in the Member States.  I would also like to praise the Commission for the rapid approval of the bridging loan for The Condor. Condor is a solid company in Germany that is not to blame for the bankruptcy at the end of the day, where many thousands of jobs are now protected accordingly and many customers can continue to fly on holiday; this company has thus been saved a little bit. Thank you to the Commission.

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As a lecturer in transport and tourism law at the university, I wanted to point out that, as in Germany, also in Poland, for many years the legislation provided for the protection of consumers in the form of insurance and bank guarantees under the threat of losing their licences. Of course, Thomas Cook's bankruptcy makes us think about changing the way we think about tourism services and the large-scale introduction of consumer protection instruments in the Union, because these services are cross-border and difficult to limit to a single country only.  I am very good at the adopted revision of the Package Travel Directive, but as legislators we must make greater efforts in the future to safeguard consumers of travel services and carriers and to take care of tourism workers. It is also important to ensure the protection of passenger flights, as has already been mentioned.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Greece is Thomas Cook's second market after Spain. The company had 68 hotels in Greece, 12 % of Greek hotels, mainly on eight islands and brought three million tourists. According to data from the Research and Forecasts Institute of the Hellenic Chamber of Hotels, we will have in 2020, due to the collapse of Thomas Cook, a loss of revenue of EUR 2.5 billion.  Given that there is a will on the part of the European Union and the Commission to allow state aid to deal with this major problem and after seeing the principle made by Germany, we must, through this resolution that we are debating here today, go further, consider a broader support framework for the economies of the countries affected, which could include State aid. , tax relief, perhaps even the creation of a Guarantee Fund to deal with similar incidents in the future. Above all, however, it could be a proposal to investigate the control of these large companies that dominate the tourism market, as well as other large companies.  Madam President, Commissioner, if European tourism is to remain competitive, it will have to draw up a new strategy, promoting the reduction of over-reliance on tour operators, the substantial diversification of the product, the strengthening of cooperation and above all it must place great emphasis on quality and not on numbers.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the collapse of the iconic British holiday company Thomas Cook is tragic and may well have been avoidable. It left 150 000 UK holidaymakers stranded – many of them children and the elderly, working class families who had worked and saved hard for a well-earned break. The collapse could cost up to 9 000 British jobs. The airline’s head office employed 450 people at Manchester Airport in my region. There were thousands of staff based at 17 high-street stores across Greater Manchester who are now being supported by the Transport Salaried Staffs’ Association (TSSA) trade union. Thomas Cook say that the Conservative government’s business secretary, Andrea Leadsom, did not even speak to their executives leading up to its collapse. Fortunately, the 600 000 holidaymakers who were affected were protected by the EU Package Travel Directive. It’s important that we recognise that as the Tories try to take us out of the EU while watering down workers’ rights and customer protection, this safety net will not be there under a Boris Johnson-led government post Brexit.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, Thomas Cook crashed a company with 22,000 workers, apart from the indirect jobs associated with it, a company with 105 aircraft and 200 hotels.  This failure, in its causes and consequences, lifts the veil that covers the reality of a sector marked by fierce competition, so often unfair, between large multinational groups and an immense fabric of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, struggling to survive. A sector marked by enormous job insecurity, high exploitation, low wages that contrast with the huge profits that capitalists have in the sector, even when associated with ruinous management practices. Others always end up paying the bill, as it turns out. A sector also marked, as we have seen, by the vulnerable position of consumers. We must act on these realities.  This bankruptcy had a significant impact in Portugal, especially in the Algarve and Madeira.  It is important that no one is left out of the instruments advertised here to respond to the damage caused by this failure.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, this debate showed that the insolvency of Thomas Cook has many causes, and that a multi-faceted approach is needed, both to prevent bankruptcy and where, despite all preventive measures failure cannot be avoided, then to address the consequences. The results and lessons learned from Thomas Cook will inform the European Commission’s implementation report on the Package Travel Directive. Such events are also moments to see where there is room for improvement, and the Commission will surely look at those, and see what more we can do. Clearly this debate provides valuable input to such a process. Many amongst you have asked for a specific tourism policy strategy. There is a new mandate ahead of us to look into that request, and indeed to evaluate the need to outline a new strategy for tourism at the EU level within the broader framework of the horizontal policies. Let me recall that under this Commission’s proposals for the next MFF, several programmes foresee support for tourism – for instance, the Structural Funds, Invest EU, the Single Market Programme, Creative Europe and Horizon Europe – and this reflects the policy of mainstreaming tourism-related investments under the diverse EU financing programmes, which makes sense in view of the inter-dependencies of tourism with other sectors of the economy.

name: Klára DOBREV

name: Josianne CUTAJAR

It is paramount that workers and consumers are always protected from the collusion and the wrongdoing of big business.

name: Karol KARSKI

text: Writing. – The consequences of the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook will be felt by the economy, the internal market and employment throughout the European Union. The resolution calls on the authorities to carry out an analysis of the reasons for Thomas Cook's bankruptcy. We ask the European Commission to make eu financial instruments available that could compensate for the damage caused to the sector. name: Klára DOBREV
text: Next item on the agenda is the Commission's statement: The threat of violent right-wing extremism (in light of recent events in Halle, Germany) (2019/2885(RSP)).

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this is an important, as well as timely, debate that we’re going to have this evening. The recent tragic events in Halle, Germany, have further underlined the very real and growing threat posed by right—wing violent extremism and, in this particular case, anti-Semitism, a threat already highlighted by the horrible slaughter of innocent people earlier this year in Christchurch. After both those events, I know that all our thoughts were with the families and friends of those involved. It’s vital that we fully recognise this threat and work together at EU level, as well as in each of our Member States, stepping up our efforts urgently to address this particular challenge. Let’s be clear: violent extremism is violent extremism, whatever hate—filled ideology fuels it. It has no place in our societies: not jihadism, nor far—right nor far—left violent extremism. Racism, anti-Semitism, xenophobia and extreme nationalism are fundamentally anti-democratic and un-European. Jo Cox, a Member of Parliament in the United Kingdom, was not murdered by a British patriot. Her life was taken by a far—right violent extremist thug. Our European countries belong to all of us, not to those who would use their supposed patriotism as an excuse for committing cold—blooded murder. The Commission welcomes the initiative that the Presidency has taken to focus on this area, and indeed this was reflected in a discussion in the Justice and Home Affairs Council on 8 October, which endorsed a set of suggestions from the Presidency. The Commission stands ready to support all the Member States and the Presidency and, obviously, to work with this House in any way possible. While our work on countering violent extremism and terrorism at EU level covers all forms of extremism, it’s fair to say that the primary focus in recent years has been on jihadi terrorism. This needs to remain a priority, given the nature of the threat, but the Commission is also increasingly focusing on, and working to tackle, violent right-wing extremism, especially through the Radicalisation Awareness Network (RAN) that is working with police officers, prison and probation staff, local government officials, teachers and others on the front line of tackling this particular challenge. And building on this work, we think there are a number of areas where we can go further – where we need to go further. First, we agree with all those who argue that we need to do more to counter violent, right—wing extremist content online. Three years ago, we signed with the platforms an EU Code of Conduct on countering illegal hate speech online. When the code was signed in 2016, 28% of such content was being removed. I’m glad to say we’re now at 72% of content. But, while the Code of Conduct has proved a very useful tool, the fight against illegal hate speech online is far from over. Unfortunately, there are no signs that the generation and circulation of such content has decreased. The Commission and the social media platforms will continue to build our cooperation within the EU Internet Forum. Indeed, a couple of weeks ago, the Internet Forum met, and this item – countering violent right—wing extremism –was at the top of the agenda. This cooperation in the Internet Forum has produced some concrete results, something that was highlighted by the companies’ rapid response to the Halle attack. The platforms were able to remove virtually all of the 200 different variants of the video and the extremist so—called manifesto – including the soundtrack used to glorify the attack – within a couple of hours. So I very much welcome the good cooperation with the companies involved in the Internet Forum. In addition, it’s important to ensure that Europol’s Internet Referral Unit has sufficient resources and capacity to monitor and refer right—wing violent extremist content, and I know that this House will support that. Europol, in fact, is now working with more than 350 different social media platforms, but there are still platforms today which refuse to cooperate in our efforts to take down illegal terrorist content online, including violent right—wing extremist content. For me, that’s one of the reasons why it’s crucial that together, as co-legislators, we advance swiftly in the negotiations on the proposal for a regulation countering terrorist content online. We need to get this done. We need to crack down on this poison and help save some lives. Let’s put in place clear and effective measures to prevent the dissemination of illegal terrorist content, including live streaming directly linked to attacks, while at the same time ensuring that we retain full respect for fundamental rights and freedom of speech. Second, the Commission stands ready to provide further support to Member States in their efforts to tackle this particular challenge. The threat posed by violent right—wing extremism has featured prominently in the discussions on the 2020 strategic orientations for a coordinated EU approach to the prevention of radicalisation. Among other things, this includes helping local and national governments to develop their action plans to prevent right—wing violent extremism, including through exit and de-radicalisation programmes. The Commission will also continue to support local authorities and cities in their efforts to tackle radicalisation. As a follow-up to the Cities Against Radicalisation conference, which we organised together with the European Committee of the Regions earlier this year, the Commission is supporting a pilot group of interested cities in building a network focused on countering radicalisation in our communities. Third – and this has also been stressed by Member States in the Council – it’s important to support our neighbours in their efforts to tackle violent extremism, particularly our partners in the Western Balkans. The Joint Action Plan on Counter-Terrorism for the Western Balkans, signed a year ago, covers counter—terrorism policy as well as prevention of all forms of radicalisation and violent extremism. To implement the Joint Action Plan, the Commission is putting in place a set of tailor—made arrangements with each of the Western Balkan partner countries, including actions for effective prevention and countering of all forms of violent extremism. We will continue to push forward our work in all of these areas, in close cooperation with our partners, including, of course, our partners here in this House.

name: Karoline EDTSTADLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has During the Austrian Presidency, it was possible to adopt a Council declaration on the fight against anti-Semitism, in which all member states committed themselves to developing a security concept for Jewish institutions and communities throughout Europe. A study by the Fundamental Rights Agency, published in December, showed just how urgent this is. Nearly 16,400 Jews from 12 Member States took part in the study, or about 96% of the Jewish population in the European Union. Conclusion: Jews feel increasingly insecure in Europe. Well, what has happened since then? Apparently too little, because otherwise it would not have been possible for a synagogue to be completely unguarded on the most important holiday of Judaism, at Yom Kippur, and that a heavily armed assassin could fight his way forward. Two people were killed, and only miraculously prevented an even greater massacre. The event in the middle of Germany will forever burn deep into the collective memory not only of the Jewish communities. It is therefore high time to remind the Member States that it is not enough to adopt declarations. Concrete action must now finally follow. The cooperation with the police, which has been lived in Austria for decades and works well, can become a model and a best practice model here. A drama like the one in Halle must not be repeated. The governments of all the Member States are required.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Renew Group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The images of Halle and other attacks in Europe are stunned. But it is not enough to mourn the victims. We must also be stunned that anti-Semitism has been gaining space in Europe for years – unnoticed, often underestimated, partly disguised as a peaceful protest, for example, by the anti-Israel anti-Semitic BDS movement. "Jew," "Yahudi" as a swear word and exclusion on our streets and in schoolyards, as well as crude conspiracy theories, show that anti-Semitism is common in everyday life. According to Eurobarometer, one in two EU citizens considers anti-Semitism to be a problem in their country. Yes, no protection from this synagogue in Halle an Yom Kippur is a question, but why are synagogues more at risk than mosques and churches? Why do we have to station police there? What shortcomings can be identified in our societies that make it possible for anti-Semitism to arise in the first place? How do young people grow up, what is taught in schools? Are we really forgotten about history? And that after the catastrophe of the Second World War? How do we deal with anti-Semitic stereotypes? How do we respond to anti-Semitic incidents? Does it really leave us indifferent that Jewish fellow citizens no longer feel safe that Jewish families are leaving Europe? That is not what we must, ladies and gentlemen. In schools, Shoah and contemporary Jewish life must be addressed in equal measure. We need tailor-made education, we need prevention. Young people must learn to deal with digital violence as early as possible; Exchange with Jewish institutions, Israeli-European youth works, active town twinning stake are all in the focus. Only the recognition that anti-Semitism threatens us all – us all – will enable us to protect Europe's community of values. We must therefore take action against anti-Semitism. Whatever its origin – whether from the right, from the left or for pseudo-religious reasons – anti-Semitism affects us all, our democracy, regardless of ideology from which it descends. That is why we need to show ways of better coexistence. We must act energetically, both as citizens and as the European Parliament.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In our minds are still the terrible images of the bloodshed of Halle. A far-right assassin has ripped two people off and two injured. The incomprehensible has happened: a man murders out of hatred for others – Jews, migrants – in the middle of Europe.  Let us make it quite clear that this attack was anti-Semitic and racist. The chemnitz hate hunts, speeches about the great exchange of populations, fascist quotes from Salvini, Le Pen's anti-immigration hate tirades, burning refugee homes, Jews beaten up when they wear a kippah, the murder of Walter Lübcke, and now Halle – all of this is connected.  For years, the right-wing forces have been working together – including here in this Parliament – to create a mood against minorities, and this is the breeding ground for hatred, which leads to a social climate in which right-wing perpetrators of violence no longer have to be afraid. Here in Parliament, too, right-wing forces are putting the lighter ever closer to the petrol canister. They are the political arm of right-wing terrorism.  I cannot repeat it often enough: we must take decisive, much more decisive action than before, against all forms of anti-Semitism and racism. Education, education and criminal prosecution; and then thank you to the Commission for setting a new priority here, that much more attention should now be paid to right-wing terrorism than before.  What happened in Halle is a highly European matter, because rights were interconnected across Europe. We definitely need better European cooperation between our investigative authorities and intelligence services, but above all a very different political focus on the fact that right-wing terrorism is linked to Europe and the world. And we must strengthen all the democratic forces that oppose right-wing incendiary speech essays and incitement throughout Europe – at the regular table, on the streets and in Parliament. Many thanks to all those who defend our open society and our European values on a daily basis.

text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Halle massacre is a heinous crime of an obnoxious psychopath. name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the delegation and the group I belong to have always been the first to condemn anti-Semitism. But unlike other groups in this House, we are against any discrimination on the belief, even those that discriminate negatively against the nationals of European nations themselves. As we feared, once again the left has tried to turn a debate about a tragic event into a synagogue in Germany into another of its dissident signalling exercises. If you really want to combat violence and extremism, spend your leftist moral superiority in a no-go zone, where Islamic law governs, or where women can't leave home peacefully. name: Martina MICHELS
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The big problem in Germany is that Auschwitz has been made the benchmark for hatred of Jews. The best example is Mr Meuthen. From education to politics, blindness on the right eye is unmistakable. Not only since today, but since the day before yesterday. Right-wing extremism and anti-Semitism have many causes, and this starts with the brutalization of language and the disrespectful treatment of one another. Unfortunately, we have been seeing this in this House for years, just with Mr Meuthen. Violence in language becomes violence in the street, hatred and hatred are destroying our democracies. name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by saying that, of course, what happened a few days ago is reprehensible.
