name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, thank you for the debate today on extremism and the growing anti-Semitism in Europe. Less than two weeks ago, there was this terrible, horrific armed attack on a synagogue in Halle, in which, as you know, two people were murdered. This horrific attack shows once again that we must do everything we can to protect Jewish life in Germany, and not only in Germany, but also in other European Member States.  Anti-Semitism is spreading again in many European countries. Gravestones in Jewish cemeteries are smeared with swastikas, neo-Nazis march through one city or another, show Hitler salutes and chanting anti-Semitic slogans. And that's just a small part of what we experience every day. At the beginning of the year, we had Charlotte Knobloch with us in the plenary session in Brussels on the occasion of the International Holocaust Remembrance Day. She confirmed that anti-Semitism is returning not only in Germany, but throughout Europe, and that jewish citizens no longer feel safe, thinking about emigration. We cannot accept that hatred of Jews is once again becoming the norm in Europe. If Jewish fellow citizens no longer feel safe, then we have failed. We must launch a new European initiative against anti-Semitism and right-wing extremism. Firstly, the Internet is not a lawless area: anyone who rails against minorities there should also have to bear the consequences. Secondly, we must educate our young people, our young people, and thirdly, and I would like to stress this too, we must nominate the parties and their representatives who incite hatred and exclusion and thus provide the spiritual breeding ground for anti-Semitism. Unfortunately, Mr Meuthen has already left; he is right, extremism from the right and the left must be combated, but when representatives of his party call the Holocaust memorial in Berlin a monument of shame, then we know what it has beaten.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Something is rotten in Europe. Right-wing extremism is on the rise in many countries of the Union. The growing violence and terrorism of the white supremacist movements is a consequence of the normalisation of far-right parties and their views. In this House too, we have parties and people with dark opinions, and as Mrs Michels said, verbal violence leads to physical violence.  The terrorist attack on the Synagogue in Halle was a heinous attack on our entire democracy. Violence and terrorism by right-wing extremism are not a new phenomenon in the history of Europe. We saw it in 1980 at the station in Bologna. We saw it at Utöya in 2011 and we saw it in New Zealand in 2019. We also saw a Europe in ruins when they gained political power during the Second World War. In several Member States today, including the UNITED Kingdom, far-right terrorism by the security police has been identified as the greatest growing threat. Europol also notes in its trend report that the number of arrests linked to far-right groups has increased for the third year in a row. Although far-right groups look different in different Member States, their targets are the same: religious and ethnic minorities, LGBTQ people, women, refugees and those perceived as political opponents. Europe must take the lead in the fight against growing nationalism and racism. Hate crimes are defined differently in the Member States, and there is a large gap between the number of offences convicted and the number of reports. I also believe that we must do more to combat hate crimes and online incitement in cooperation with, among others, service providers. Hatred and violence are not forces of nature. We can stop the destructive spiral. We can build a better Europe.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As now in Halle, people in Europe have been arbitrarily murdered for years by racists, fanatics and right-wing extremists. And yet, the political responses to this are always the same. Some – as the CDU now does in Germany – want to ban computer games, others want to pull up border bars again and others simply want to collect even more data and restrict civil rights. None of this would have prevented the attack in Halle. Police presence would have actually prevented the attack, and that is why our Member States must finally make the resources and staff available and also improve police cooperation. But every anti-Semitic attack in Europe is indeed a state failure, and I am particularly ashamed, as a German, that Jews in Germany and Europe must feel insecure again. But what Mr Meuthen has just said, that the rise in this anti-Semitism is mainly due to immigration, migration, is simply factually wrong. The figures from the Federal Criminal Police Office show otherwise. Overall, anti-Semitic crimes have increased, indeed, even those with the background of foreigners, but far-right crimes have risen even more sharply. In 2018, there were 1,600 far-right crimes and 154 with a foreign background. So if you don't say clearly that anti-Semitism is above all right-wing, you have too lean a foot, and we must resolutely oppose that hatred.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Hatred of Jews is present in all rooms and everywhere, even here, even if the wolves dress in sheep's clothing. The heinous attack in Halle is a disgusting expression of anti-Semitism and it is a disgrace to the EU that all Member States have decided that the EU should be. At the same time, there are many of us who are not surprised. The failure to stand up for and protect people who exercise their full right to believe in what they want, shape their lives as they please and live a life of freedom has often had the most dire consequences before the attack in Halle. We must put an end to violent extremism. We must invest vigorously in preventive measures that have an effect long before the terrible thing happens. We Greens therefore call on the Commission to continue to call on the Member States to work proactively against radicalisation and to cooperate even more.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, any violent extremism is a security threat. Now we are only condemning what the right has done. Why would I do that? Can't the EU stand the truth? Statistics show that the violent extreme left and Islamists are by far the biggest security threat in Europe. Once again, Jews have been subjected to persecution in many countries and even exile. Violent Islamists are their greatest persecutor, and this is due to uncontrolled immigration. Of course, the Jews deserve all our support. Why is such a completely one-eyed subject even being brought to the table? We are on a dangerous path if the violent extreme left and Islamists are sanctified beyond criticism and condemnation.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – The murder in Halle is a drastic symptom of the wave of anti-Semitism that has long been growing in Germany, but also in France. Today it is better not to show Jewish identity in Berlin or Paris, and please do not say that this is the case everywhere in Europe. I would like my German colleagues to take a little bit of care of their country. It is also worth recalling the murders carried out by the national socialist underground in Germany and the unexplained role of the services in this case. There is a problem of radicalisation on both sides: left and right. In Germany, for example, there is an increasingly threatened problem of freedom of expression and academic freedom, and attacks on university professors are multiplying. Recently, this has been the case for our colleague from the previous term, Bernd Lucke. In France, we have had cases of disproportionate use of force in relation to the 'yellow vests' movement. We watch people on the streets of many European cities every day in the news, but as Frans Timmermans argues, all this is legal. So we can calmly address the debate on the sexual education of Poles.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, the rise of the far right is a dangerous reality that brings us to the worst ghosts in Europe. But there is something at least as dangerous, and it is how the far-right agenda, proposals and codes of that far right are being bought by the big parties of the neoliberal grand coalition. In Catalonia, In France or in the Mediterranean, exceptionality has become the alibi to justify cuts in rights and freedoms, normalizing by the way to the far right.  European politics is now in an accelerated 'lepenisation', which threatens democracy. On this continent democracy was defended and conquered from the anti-gassm. Let's remember that.  Just as it is not enough today to take Franco out of the Valley of the Fallen, but it is necessary to draw Francoism from the Spanish institutions, in Europe what is urgent is to combat far-right policies and their violence regardless of the acronym under which they hide. That's why it's more important than ever to raise the cry again of "they won't happen!"

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, the attack in Halle is horrific. It is so shocking that so many celebrating Yom Kippur, so many Jewish institutions, now need police protection. But I have a number of concerns about how we react: we shouldn’t be too simplistic. To those who say anti-Semitism is confined to the extreme right, I have to say – as somebody on the left in British politics – that, to my shame, anti-Semitism is far too much of a factor in left-wing organisations there. I don’t say that to score left-right tit—for—tat points, but simply to just not point fingers and to be honest.  I also say that, while it’s very tempting when we see extreme violence of this nature to clamp down, I would urge the German authorities and the people in this Parliament in relation to their nation states not to call for bans or attacks on free speech. The clamping—down on anything in the name of hate speech might be what the EU does, but it should not be what freedom-lovers do.  And I say to my colleagues in Parliament: you should be careful about bandying around accusations of hate speech to anyone who disagrees with you: the real hate—speech—mongers are the murderers and the extremists, whereas some of us who get labelled with those labels are actually the lovers of freedom and the fighters against anti-Semitism and against all forms of racism and discrimination. (Applause)

name: Javier ZARZALEJOS
text: – Madam President, thank you for this timely debate which allows us not only to look at those who have perpetrated these crimes, but also their victims. And when we look at his victims, we find again anti-Semitism and Judeophobia, which are at the root of this criminal impulse.  The far right, yes. But anti-Semitism nests in the far left, nests in jihadism, nests in Islamism. All make this their common cause and to that are added defamatory speeches, socially accepted harassment and, of course, all those who deny or trivialize the Holocaust open the way for major violence.  Silence has always been the most effective and perverse ally of anti-Semitism. It's the famous "we didn't know anything, we didn't hear anything, we didn't see anything." For now we do know, now we do hear, and now we do see that anti-Semitism is advancing and must be fought, because in Europe we know that when anti-Semitism is at its best it heralds tragedy.  Now in Europe we are talking again about a silent exodus from the Jews. Let me, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress at the moment that, in Spain, thanks to an initiative of the People's Party, over the last four years, more than 31,000 Sephardic Jews, descendants of those who were expelled in 1492, have received Spanish nationality in an act of recognition as Spaniards and as Europeans.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab An important word has been said today in this debate: Auschwitz. I come from the country where this concentration camp built by the Nazis was operating. But Auschwitz was not built at the time of the construction of the crematorium. Auschwitz started much earlier. When we call someone a rainbow plague, when we set fire to a synagogue, when we set fire to a mosque, when we shoot defenseless people who are refugees, when we set fire to an asylum seeker's house, then we build a second Auschwitz.  In this room are representatives of a party whose leader calls refugees people who spread germs. There are politicians in this House who have supported a ban on the creation of so-called LGBT-free zones in my country. In this Room there is also the widow of my friend Pawle Adamowicz, president of Gdańsk, who was murdered only because someone disagreed with his views. Because when he asked to stop the rebuke to him, when he supported the Equality Parade, when he supported refugees, no one reacted. Today, his widow, who became an MEP, is here with us. However, this memento should accompany us. I also come from the country of Solidarity, not just Auschwitz, and that is why I am asking for this solidarity. Not nuanced hatred, not normalizing hate, but naming hate by name, because it has its name, it has its own party symbol, it has its name. You have to call things by name before the second Auschwitz is built. And that's what I'm asking for today.

name: Laurence FARRENG
text: Madam President, two weeks ago, a man opened fire in Halle, committing an anti-Semitic terrorist attack on a synagogue on Yom Kippur Day. He broadcast his acts live on the internet for 35 minutes. Although reported, these images have been viewed by several thousand people and shared. These facts are reminiscent of the Christchurch massacre, which targeted Muslims. They call for swift and effective action: to create a strong European framework by concluding the trilogues on the removal of terrorist content online. The current legislation constituted by the Audiovisual Media Services Directive and the code of conduct signed in 2016 by the major Players of the Net is not sufficient.  We need to speed up the removal of content and reach all platforms and online forums. Thus, the Internet will no longer be used to trivialize extremist causes. We must also note the ignorance of our history. One in ten young Europeans does not know the Holocaust. So let's fight the root evil in schools, high schools and universities, so we will make internet users freer, and therefore more responsible.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For days people have been talking about the incident in Halle, people have been talking to each other for days, passing each other. The right pretends to have nothing to do with the incident, as if there were nothing to call the Holocaust a bird's-eye shot of history, as if there was nothing in calling for a 360-degree turn in memory politics. Even today, they speak as if they have nothing to do with it. I myself, a member of the Jewish community, myself, as a German, as a European, I was ashamed when I heard about this incident. And yet I stand by the fact that this incident came about for the right reasons – it is important to acknowledge that.  But there is also a lot to do on the left of the centre. Of course, we too are making it too easy for ourselves if we only look at the right. Many such debates are revolving around. The endless debates that we have now – whether single offenders or not, whether gamer scene or not, whether AfD ban or not: all in vain if we do not find the right people responsible. We are responsible ourselves, not all of us guilty, but all responsible. Instead of talking about tacheles, we also remain in rituals, about our own behaviour and about the behaviour of our families and colleagues. And yes, we can also do simple things here, we can secure the NGOs that are fighting against right and left anti-Semitism. We can strengthen the framework conditions for minimum security standards for Jewish institutions throughout Europe. We can also clarify the framework decision on racism, in such a way that hate crime is finally prosecuted in all Member States. And it is precisely the new President of the Commission who can do a very simple thing to send a signal that the fight against anti-Semitism is a matter of the utmost: as President of the Commission, she can put the wonderful Katharina von Schnurbein, the coordinator for the fight against anti-Semitism, on her staff. That would be a real start for the new Commission.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the attack on 9 October at the Halle synagogue once again marks the return of anti-Semitism to our continent for several years. More than a condemnation without weakness of horror, it is the causes of anti-Semitism that need to be singled out and eradicated.  So yes, if at the synagogue in Halle, it is a neo-Nazi criminal who has committed this terrorist crime, for 30 years, with a few rare exceptions, these attacks are the work of terrorists of Arab-Muslim origin, as indicated, as early as 2004, the Advisory Commission on Human Rights. In France, the names Halimi, Knoll, Hyper Cacher, recall the deadly violence of radical Islam. Moreover, the anti-Zionism uttered by many Muslim countries and relayed ad nauseam by the extreme left in Europe is the antechamber of anti-Semitism.  So to attack the sources of anti-Semitism is to urgently organize the closure of all Salafist mosques in Europe, and it is also to draw diplomatic consequences from the systematic denigration of Israel and strongly condemn its use by the increasingly violent movements of the extreme left.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, if the cowardly attack at the Halle synagogue, especially on Great Aerial Day, makes one thing clear, it is that anti-Semitism is still very much alive in 2019. In fact, the figures show a shocking increase in the number of incidents. Anti-Semitism is a multi-headed monster: right, left and Islamic. And we just don't seem to be able to get a handle on it. I therefore call on the European Commission to make the fight against it a top priority for the coming years. Free up enough manpower and resources to tackle much-needed coordination, together with the Member States that need to tackle anti-Semitism much harder. Mr President, we can no longer look away.

name: Sira REGO
text: – Madam President, there is certainly a long list of victims: Pavlos Fyssas , I think Mr Lagos knows the case well - Jo Cox, Carlos Palomino, the Utoya massacre, constant attacks on the streets — just four days ago, a group of neo-Nazis brutally beat up a young man in Barcelona. Far-right violence is not the result of a punctual exalted man, however much many and many strive to say it here. It is the product of a chain of responsibilities that begins with some of those who sit on the front bench, but also those who agree with them or those who lay them down to split the armchairs.  There is a direct link between hate speeches that criminalize migrants, justifying violence against women, against LGTBI people, and thugs who perform violence on the streets. And the sad thing is that, far from putting forward a serious reflection, we see this Parliament and the European Commission assuming irresponsiblely, not only the names, but the ideas that neo-traders coin with their exclusionary speeches.  This is credited by the unfortunate title of the Protection portfolio of our European Way of Life. Pure xenophobia. Of course, it would be better for this Parliament and Europe if we took note of what an old Spanish anti-fascism fighter said: "fascism is not disputed, it is being combated".  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Louis STEDMAN-BRYCE
text: blue-card question. – I just think it is really interesting when I hear statements like the one that you have made. As a gay black man, I have been branded as a racist, homophobe, Nazi... by people that sit on the other side of the Chamber. I just think it is really hypocritical that you would say such things, and it is divisive. This isn’t about community, this isn’t about what you claim makes Europe. This is about nastiness, this is about racism, this is about creating hate – which is what we’re not about on this side of the Chamber. So I suggest that you look at yourself and reflect on what you’re saying before you use this language, because the danger is that the language you are using when the real Nazis come along, when the real racists come along, you will not be able to identify them.

name: Sira REGO
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Stedman-Bryce, this has nothing to do with individual issues, this has to do with political positions. And what many of these colleagues are proposing and many of these groups also have a lot to do with systematic human rights violations and putting a lot of people on the line.  Therefore, this is not simply a personal matter of yours. These are specific political lines and ideas used by their political organizations, not each individually.  Surely my personal circumstances would also invite me to have other positions, but here a political position is defended, and that of their organizations what it does is constantly raise human rights violations and justify them.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her If I have understood this correctly – that is, if the interpreters have interpreted it correctly – it has just been said that here the people who sit opposite, that is, we, give our hand to right-wing terrorism. That is a clear insult! I expect the Bureau to call on the honourable Member to order this.

name: Nicola BEER
text: Mr! I did not notice that in the debate. We can do this on the basis of ... (Interjede by Mr Fest) Let me make excuses. When it's your turn, you have the microphone. Otherwise I have the microphone. We will review this on the basis of the Minutes and then address it. In other words, we will continue in the debate until then.

name: Lance FORMAN
text: – Madam President, at the same moment that a murderer was shooting at the doors of a synagogue in Halle on Yom Kippur, the holiest day of my year, I was standing outside the doors of my own synagogue in London wearing a bullet-proof vest, assisting with the security of my own community. Tragically, Jewish people around the world must still protect ourselves from attack only two generations after the Holocaust, of which my own father is a survivor. Anti-Semitism is a stain on our society, but also a warning sign. But what is the cause of the upsurge now? Racism and extremism grow when people are resentful at the failure of economics and democracy. The reason I joined the Brexit Party was not because of sovereignty or immigration or bureaucracy, but because I fear the dangerous road that Europe is heading down. Its dysfunctional and damaging euro currency and the desire for empire has led to the most extreme Europe of any time since World War II, on both right and left. This may be my last speech in this House, so be warned. The urgent priority facing this institution is a renewal, as a partnership of independent free nations, by celebrating, not obstructing, the dreams of the people we represent.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, last summer, the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights published a report. This shows that anti-Semitism has increased significantly in Europe over the past five years. Almost 30% of Jews in the European Union have been seriously harassed in the last 12 months because of their Jewish heritage. Almost 38% of respondents to this survey said they were thinking of emigration, away from Europe. Unfortunately, the recent attack in Halle has confirmed these figures and findings. The figures are quite disturbing and we are talking about the democratic rule of law here. It is therefore essential that the new European Commission makes anti-Semitism the spearhead of its policy. This can be done in many ways, for example: to encourage Member States to ensure the safety of Jewish communities and, if necessary, to pay for security; encourage Member States to draw attention to the Holocaust, anti-Semitism and the history of Judaism in Europe in all educational programmes; and last but not least, the new European Commission must make the fight against anti-Semitism a chef's alche. In other words, Commissioner Von der Leyen, as Chairwoman, must place the EU coordinator for combating anti-Semitism under her personal competence. As the European Union, we cannot allow the shocking development of Jew hatred for what it is.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, first I want to offer my condolences to all those affected by the synagogue attack in Halle, especially the families of the two people who were killed. No words can ever heal their suffering, but I know that the whole of the European Parliament stands with you today. The recent act of terror in Halle is yet another appalling pre-meditated attack on the Jewish community. Anti-Semitism and the threat of right-wing extremism is, sadly, on the rise across Europe. France reported a 74% increase, Germany more than 60%, and 10% in the UK. This is the highest number in the UK since records began in 1984, with the anti-terror ‘Prevent’ programme reporting a shocking 36% increase in far-right cases in 2018. I represent more than 30 0001 Jewish constituents in the North-West of England, and I know we cannot be complacent. The best way to tackle anti-Semitism is through intercultural dialogue, education, and a zero-tolerance policy regarding anti-Semitic acts or use of language, and I am proud of our Manchester Muslim Jewish Forum. Reconciliation between the peoples of Europe, peaceful development on the basis of indivisible and universal human rights, genuine democracy and pluralism: these did and must always underpin our vision for a shared Europe. We must draw on the lessons of a shameful past which brought tyranny to our continent. A nation and a continent that forgets its past has no future. 1 Figure corrected at the request of the speaker (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Lance Forman)

name: Nicola BEER
text: Colleagues, please. It’s the right of a speaker to accept or not accept. It’s the right of the speaker, sir. I am sorry, we will continue in the debate.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Jana and Kevin are the victims of the Halle bombing. A forty-year-old woman who enjoyed pop music. He, a young painter in his twenties. Life and projects eliminated by a murderer full of hate. He shot. But there's a breeding ground that encourages those actions. We must denounce the "what", the rights extremism and anti-Semitic. But we must also change the "how". The "what" is the discourse of the irresponsible who obtain votes by making "others", hateful, distinct, expendable. We must prevent, investigate, but we must also remember what this rights and anti-Semitic extremism brought us in the past.  The "how" are the talking busts, the recitators who never listen. In front of them, peace and word. Dialogue, pluralism and empathy. There are no "other" in this context. We live together people with rights, human beings like Jana, Kevin, Mohamed or Salom.

name: Magid MAGID
text: – Madam President, friends, as-salamu alaykum. I would like to start by sending my deepest condolences and extend my unwavering eternal solidarity to the Jewish community, especially those who have been attacked or affected in the cruel, blood-thirsty act of far-right terror in Halle. It makes me angry. Beyond angry. Angry because we are here again, and angry because we have to be angry again. Just how much longer do religious minorities have to scream into the indifferent face of Europe, screaming stop? Stop normalising the far right. Stop entertaining them. Stop being seduced by polling numbers, voting patterns and political expediency. The thing is, when we degrade racial, ethnic and religious minorities to justify deadly borders, approval ratings and foreign military interventions, we threaten the lives and well-being of all our citizens. So let me put it simply: a religious attack on our Jewish brothers and sisters, as well as our Muslim brothers and sisters, is an attack on all of us. So to the toxic section of the European press, to the hateful, inactive and indifferent politicians, and to the online merchants of dehumanisation: in a fairer world, you would be charged as a co-defendant of every hate crime. So let us promise to degrade and defeat the forces of the far right, and to protect our Jewish siblings, Muslim siblings and all our other siblings from religious minorities, whether that be on the streets, in prayer, or in every single city, town and village across Europe.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the author of the events in Halle has rightly been described as a fool, but it is a fact, unfortunately, that the unjustified aversion to the State of Israel is growing stronger. Only a few months ago, right here in Strasbourg, Israeli flags were banned from entering the stadium. In Italy, it has happened several times that, during the celebrations of 25 April, the far-left acronyms prevented the Jewish Brigade from participating, in the name of hatred against the State of Israel. There are no longer any Islamic attacks and attacks in the name of anti-Zionism. Anti-Semitism in Europe has different but equally reprehensible ideological matrices.  We are prisoners of fanaticism and we are tired of being so. Perhaps we should learn precisely from the State of Israel, where, despite having been live with terrorism for years, they have never lowered their heads, they have not renounced their roots, their traditions, their own system of values, as Europe has all too often done. Terrorism must be combated every day by all means, just as Israel teaches us.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, violence with a political or religious background is not new in Europe, but we should be very concerned that we are witnessing more frequent attacks on political dissidents, religious buildings and communities, as well as members of vulnerable social groups. A sense of deep frustration has crept into parts of European societies that manifests itself in the worst ways we must clearly condemn and sanction. The attack in the town of Halle during which two people were killed in front of a synagogoga is another reminder that violent individuals and violent ideas reside on all sides of the political spectrum. They are equally unacceptable and we have to deal with them equally. The desec of places of worship and cemeteries are particularly common in some Member States. It's not just minority religious communities that are being attacked, and bullies aren't just right-wing radicals. Left-wing extremists are frequent attackers on Catholic religious buildings and we would also have to speak openly about this in this house. Colleagues, crime is a crime, a criminal is a criminal, no matter what color they are or the nation or beliefs.

name: Niyazi KIZILYÜREK
text: – Madam President, unfortunately I cannot speak my mother tongue – Turkish – in this House, although it is one of the official languages of Cyprus, where I come from. So I will pick up other languages: I will go on in German and finish in Greek. Let us be clear: there is no right-wing radicalism without nationalism. And nationalism means violence. The founding fathers of the EU knew this very well. That is why they wanted to overcome nationalism and bring about a post-national unification. Unfortunately, however, we are seeing nationalist tendencies and national selfishness all over Europe today. Let us also be clear: far-right violence is mainly male violence aimed at women, homosexuals, Jews, Muslims and refugees. In order to combat right-wing radicalism, we need a redefinition of "we". We must strengthen the European, plural, democratic 'we' versus the national 'we', on which right-wing radicalism invokes and seeks to establish homogeneity and eliminate plurality and diversity, and thus everything that the EU is supposed to be.  Πρέπει να οικοδομήσουμε την κοινή ευρωπαϊκή μας συνείδηση. Χρειαζόμαστε πολιτικές που θα προωθήσουν την κοινοτική ένταξη. (Η Πρόεδρος διακόπτει τον ομιλητή)

name: Miroslav RADAČOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, right-wing extremism is the worst thing a human being could have created. May western European friends not be mad at me, but I have to be objective. Historically, our Western European friends are the founders of ideologies of both right-wing and left-wing extremism. They are the founders of the ideologies of fascism, Nazism, anti-Semitism, racial supremacy, two world wars, guillotine, colonialism, atomic bombs and concentration camps. Slavic peoples, including my nation, have never been the ideological creators of these perverse, dirty and nasty ideologies, and, if they were, quickly got rid of them. Unless the European Union accepts the human and character-pure, historically non-extremist society of the Slavic peoples into the social and cultural realities of Europe, and if Europe is not united from Vladivostok to Lisbon, the threat of right-wing extremism will still be there and will not be helped by even the strictest measures. And now listen to me all: Slovakia has the most Fair Among Nations awards per population. I'm proud to be Slovak.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Madam President, representatives of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The fact that we are talking about Halle here today – Halle is located in Saxony-Anhalt, in Germany, it is my constituency, it is my homeland – makes me very distressed today. I have been a Member of the European Parliament for more than five years, and I have always fought for my homeland here at European level. However, I would have liked us to have never had to have had such a debate. I would like to thank all the colleagues who took part in this minute's silence in Parliament in Brussels less than two weeks ago and who showed their sympathy. This has also had a corresponding effect on the people in my country, and it has impressed people a great deal. We have many, many thousands of extremists in Germany – right-wing extremists, left-wing extremists. Many of them are also known to the authorities. This perpetrator was not. This is a perpetrator that the authorities did not know before. And we also have something in Germany – it must also be said that it is also part of the truth: we have seen the advent of language in the Bundestag, but also in many state parliaments, which I did not think possible. We are experiencing Nazi language in German parliaments. And these people, these representatives of the people, as they call themselves, are not legally guilty. However, they provide the breeding ground for what has also happened in Halle. Words become deeds. We must stand together here, we must stand together, and we must not provide a stage for such people.

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: – Madam President, above all in having this debate, our thoughts are with the victims in the attack in Halle and their loved ones. Across the world, right-wing extremism is threatening various groups in our society – from Christchurch to Halle, you are dealing with people who think they are superior because of their race, gender and beliefs. We all know what this kind of thinking leads to. Far-right internet platforms make it much easier to nurture their hateful world view, and social media are the weapon they use to spread their awful ideas. Therefore, we need to demand openness and cooperation of social media platforms and tech companies. Algorithms need to be open so that we can understand what drives the spread of information which terrorists use to their advantage. So I call upon the Commission to push big tech companies and internet platforms to disclose this information and provide transparency.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This anti-Semitic attack in Halle is just the latest incident of this racist development in Europe. Arson attacks are being carried out on Sinti in Germany and Italy, Roma are being deliberately murdered, all minorities are subjected to hatred and hatred. We have these haters and arsonists sitting here in Parliament. Your flat slogans, your dull racism, are the reason for the political violence against minorities on our continent. Your folk fantasies serve as a mirage that distracts from real social problems for which you have no solutions to offer. You can only split, rush, rush and rush. Dear friends! The way in which we protect the most vulnerable members of our society is a measure of our democracy. Anti-Semitism and anti-Gypsyism have no place here. Kevin S. and Jana L. are not said to have died in vain. We must pursue right-wing networks across Europe resolutely. We must provide more support to civil society in its work against right-wing hatred.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Right-wing terrorism in Germany is a danger, but unfortunately we do not know how great this danger is and where the source lies. name: Leila CHAIBI
text: Madam President, first of all, I would like to express my thoughts to the victims of the Halle attack, murdered by a far-right activist and my total compassion to their loved ones. In France, lately, we are witnessing the proliferation of violent discourse by an extreme right driven by hatred. Just a few days ago, an elected official of the National Rally, Julien Odoul, violently took on a Muslim mother who accompanied her son on a school trip, simply because she was wearing a veil.  The trivialization of these hateful words and acts is also maintained by the programming on a television channel, in prime time, of a polemicist named Eric Zemmour, who has been convicted of provoking racial hatred. So, from my place here, to the left of this Chamber, I see them particularly well those on the right, on the far right of this Chamber. They're right in front of me. There are many of them, for sure, but for all that, we must not trivialize their presence. We must not let their ideas spread. Ladies and gentlemen, let us resist their will to hate with our will to live together, with our benevolence, with our diversity. This is the only way to ensure that attacks like Halle's don't happen again.

name: Lena DÜPONT
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. On 9 October, a few days ago, there was a bloody attack in Halle in which, as we have heard several times today, two people were killed and two seriously injured. Cynically and purposefully, the perpetrator chose the highest holiday of Judaism, Yom Kippur, and planned to carry out a massacre on that day.  In Germany, anti-Semitic crimes increased by almost 14% in 2018 compared to the previous year. They start with verbal hostility and they obviously end in murder. Far-right extremists are finding more and more ways and platforms, even off the Internet, to connect and openly display their anti-democratic views. Apparently, there are more and more people who define their identity by degrading and excluding others. They stand out through verbal derailments, thus laying the breeding ground for physical attacks up to the attacks. Nine out of ten European Jews feel that anti-Semitism has increased in their home country.  This is not only a cause for concern, but above all it is also a cause for action. Prevention measures are important, but they are obviously no longer enough. We must not show tolerance towards those who argue with hatred and hatred and who oppose our liberal democratic order. I therefore thank my colleagues in this House this evening for having this important debate, and I hope and I build on the fact that we stand together against hatred and hatred, against incitement and attacks.

text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Out of hatred against certain groups of people and minorities, people have been murdered several times. Against hatred and hatred, all people must stand together and stand together against it, instead of now putting gamers or Internet users under general suspicion. The policy response to such acts must be more democracy and civic participation, a more open society and more humanity, instead of now taking out long-prepared surveillance plans or bans on anonymity that could not have stopped the Assassin of Halle in its approach. We must never give up our values when it comes to tackling violence, otherwise the terrorists will have won.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are certainly all close to the Jewish community for what has happened in Germany. This is a serious incident, to be condemned, absolutely, and we are against all kinds of racist or religious violence and crime.  That is why I wonder how Europe is silent about other events in recent weeks. In early October in Paris, a man killed three policemen and an officer with a knife. He was an Islamic extremist and is being investigated for terrorism. Also in Manchester, the same thing: a man stabbed five people in a shopping centre. Here, too, terrorism is being investigated. In Milan, in mid-September, an illegal immigrant stabbed a soldier in the throat shouting 'Allah akbar'.  So why is there no mention of the many violent cases of anti-Semitism in France? Why does Europe not discuss the danger of terrorism, Islamic fundamentalism in many European cities, islamic ghettos where fundamentalism lingers? Why is there no mention of the danger of Isis terrorists returning to Europe, not least because of Turkey's intervention in Syria, perhaps with boats in the middle of the sea? I would like Europe to look at that as well.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The recent events in Halle have shocked us again, because this is another hate crime that painfully tinges our society. It is certainly no secret that hate speech issues are the motivation for my political and social commitment. This is not just about anti-Semitism, racism, homophobia or terrorism. It is about democracy and about setting the line between freedom of expression and hate speech.  As legislators, we must set ourselves ambitious targets for combating online and offline hate speech, as well as a cross-cutting view of this phenomenon, taking into account its inevitable consequences for society. In this context, I stress with all my strength, including from my personal experience, that responsibility lies with all of us. Shifting the blame from one to the other is not good. Everyone has to start with themselves and we all have the same guilt. And I emphasize: we can put walls, we can blame the police, we can put fences in front of churches, in front of mosques, but the most important thing is education, education and education.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Madam President, the right-wing violent extremism, the events of last October in Halle, only remind us that it can be the Jewish people, it can be the Muslim people, it can be the Afros, it can be the LGTBI collectives, it can be the immigrants and perhaps, moreover, the refugees, who suffer the hate speech. But it is of no use to come to this Parliament to make great speeches on European values if then in our regional parliaments, in our Member States, we agree with those right-wing parties that make hate speech an apology; and in many town halls, in many communities in Spain, those who make bombastic speeches here agree, favoring that these speeches be on their political agenda.  I believe that we need to build Europe by dumping resources in the town halls, in the regions, through the European Social Fund, through all these cohesion funds, in order to serve as a prevention. Without prevention, we will not combat hate speech. We defend Europe, defend coexistence, and then not be sorry for not doing our best. We're on time.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, the violent extremism of the extreme right, of which halle's attacks were an expression, must be fought without respite, but also with the awareness that it is an integral part of an ongoing process of upsurge of the extreme right and fascist forces in Europe. A process that has causes and responsible. It is inseparable from policies that attack social and labour rights, national sovereignty, democracy, policies in favour of great capital that aggravate injustices and social inequalities, that is, also the policies that the European Union has been promoting.  The same European Union which is committed to an abject and dangerous historical revisionism of which the laundering of fascism is an integral part, the deplorable attempt to equate communism and fascism, thereby minimizing the crimes of fascism, equating victims and executioners, erasing the role of communists and other democrats in the struggle for freedom and democracy.  This is also what must be fought. No tolerance or complacency can be for an ideology that belongs to the dustbin of history and should not leave.

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Commissioner, of course, all forms of extremism must be condemned, and if someone shoots at families with children for political or religious reasons, they are in any case a madman. But I don't understand why there's only talk of right-wing extremism, like there's no other extremism. Let's put the same meter on everyone. Why don't you also talk about jihadists, about Islamic extremists who are also committing huge crimes in Europe, they are committing terrorist attacks in which they shout Allahu akbar, they create no-go zones where the police don't dare go anymore, and the European Union is silent. Why are you not talking about the other side, about left-wing extremism, about the antifa street movement, who are attacking politicians from the opposite spectrum, whether colleagues from the AfD or others. In Slovakia, a young blogger was recently attacked last week for disagreeing with their conservative views. And this is completely overlooked. Commissioner, that is worse than totalitarianism.

In our European legal culture, we have a binding Charter of Human Rights, which guarantees freedom of religion, and let us really see how this freedom is ensured that some Jewish groups are afraid to subscribe, for example here in France, to their faith. name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Madam President, I too, like everybody in this room, was appalled by the murders in Halle and elsewhere, and I offer my deep, deep condolences to the families engaged. But I want to remind the European Parliament that last month, in this very place, we debated remembrance for the EU to build a common historical narrative, and our colleague, Mr Nicholas Fest, sitting just over there, reminded us that the motion that we were debating had forgotten to remember the holocaust, and he proposed an amendment that it be inserted into that motion. And despite support from this side and many other MEPs, many left-wing groups rejected this, and that motion was not carried. What signal does that send, when the very Parliament of Europe turns its back on remembering the holocaust? We need to not just speak; we need to make sure that our actions and our beliefs count in this House too.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone who has contributed to this debate very much. It’s a very important debate. We have to keep shining a light on the issues that have been raised this evening.  There have been other occasions when we’ve discussed anti-Semitism. There can be no doubt about the Commission’s commitment to tackle that. You’ve discussed it at length with my colleagues Frans Timmermans and Věra Jourová, and I think there can be no doubt that the new Commission will continue its efforts to tackle anti-Semitism and tackle racism, xenophobia and extreme nationalism because these are fundamentally opposed to our shared values.  At the same time, we need to continue our efforts to counter violent extremism. I said it at the beginning of this debate and I shall say it at the end of this debate: violent extremism, whatever its source – that is, far-right violent extremism, far-left violent extremism, Jihadi extremism, I’m not making some sort of distinction between those – we must focus our efforts to tackle violent extremism.  I agree with those who have spoken about the need to focus on prevention, to counter the radicalisation that can lead to that hatred and violence, and we must do that through education and we must do that through our effective engagement with civil society, that is, local government, teachers, but also police officers, prison and probation staff. All those who find themselves on the front line in this fight. And we must work as part of this effort with the social media platforms because, whether we like it or not, this is the vehicle and the vector that spreads and accelerates so much of this hateful, violent and illegal content. It’s not because I have some problem with the social media platforms – they are being abused to spread this hatred and illegal content – but we do need to work with them. The violent extremist activity at Halle which we’ve all spoken about during this debate was carried out with a commentary in English. It was designed to spread a message across all our countries and possibly wider – a message of violence and hatred.  Because some of the lessons that have been learnt after Christchurch were put into effect, it was, as somebody said during the debate, only half an hour after that live-streaming that it was being taken down. That meant that it was actually seen as live-streaming by a relatively small number of people. But unfortunately that doesn’t stop it spreading. It’s spread to various channels, social networks, fora, image boards. It is still possible to see this content, as it is possible still to see content from the Christchurch attack, which is why we have to find more effective ways – working with the social media platforms – of targeting and eliminating this content because it does poison minds. I, like many of you who have spoken, believe that our strength is our values, and we need to remember what we stand for as we take forward this fight against extremism, hatred and violence. And it’s going to help us. Those values are going to help us to win this fight.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the criminalisation of sex education in Poland (2019/2891(RSP)).

name: Nicola BEER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Parliament has invited the Commission to issue a statement on criminalisation of sexual education in Poland. As I speak to you, to our knowledge, there’s no such legislation currently in force, and the Commission does not comment on draft legislation. But we can only note our regret that it’s necessary for us to debate this subject this evening. When it comes to education policy, as you know, Article 165 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union sets out that Member States are responsible for the content of teaching and the organisation of their education systems. That said, the Union does encourage cooperation between the Member States in this area. Curricula regarding sexual education are part of teaching. That said, the School Education Gateway – which is Europe’s online platform on school education for teachers, school leaders, policy-makers and experts – has opened a survey on the topic of sexual education to try and understand better the views of teachers who work in this field. The survey is open until 20 November, available in 23 languages, and the results of that survey will be published on the School Education Gateway. When it comes to the criminal law: again, as you know, Article 83 of the TFEU sets out that Union competence comes into play for serious crimes with a cross-border dimension. Now that does include the offence of sexual exploitation of women and children. Indeed, as you know, Directive 2011/93 criminalises sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children and child pornography. The Directive requires Member States to take appropriate measures, including education and training, to discourage and reduce the demand that fosters all forms of sexual exploitation of children. Examples include campaigns on the consequences of violating the law as well as the short- and long-term damage to those who are caught up in this vile crime. The Commission will make use of its enforcement powers under the Treaties to ensure that this Directive is implemented fully and correctly, and that includes ensuring that national laws do not interfere with the purpose of the Directive of preventing the sexual abuse and sexual exploitation of children.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, let me just say that the proposed changes to the criminal law in Poland, which de facto criminalise and penalise the sexual education of youngsters, is not just an example of a particularly hyper-ideological and retrograde proposal, it’s also going against the very basic notions of modern education. In fact, like my colleague, I find it quite impossible that, in 21st-century Europe, teachers would actually be threatened with prison time for explaining the practice and benefits of condoms to youngsters. Normally, governments in Europe – and all across the world – do their utmost to invest in education: education which is free from ideology and equips children with the necessary knowledge and skills to navigate through their professional and social lives. What we see here is actually the very opposite: depriving children of this very right. The authors of this legislation claim that it is intended to protect children and young people from sexual deprivation. The problem is that it might in fact cause the very opposite because, without proper knowledge about sexual abuse by potential victims, it may well be that sexual violence will increase as a result, because making sexuality taboo is typically an invitation for paedophiles. Any attempt to effectively ban sexual education would therefore be to the detriment of the children’s well—being and safety. The other negative consequence would be to scare off and discourage professional teachers from doing their job, given the harsh penalties involved. This would send a very bad signal to the entire profession and create an atmosphere of fear and persecution. Perhaps, as some might suggest, these harsh sentences would not in fact be applied and the law would be interpreted in a fairly lenient fashion. However, given the aggressive campaign of scapegoating and hatred against, say, the LGBTI community in Poland over the past few months, it is very difficult to believe these assurances. Therefore, from my perspective, it would be best if the proposal is taken back.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, people should have the right to learn about love and sexuality. When young people have questions about their gender and sexuality, they need answers. Science is telling us that some young people already at the age of 12 or 13 are beginning to have questions about their sexuality, about love or about their body. It is important that young people get answers. It is important that they learn to love, to say no, and to get self-confidence. The worst thing you can do is to ban sex education. If you ban sex education in public schools, young people will ask others or they will be anxious. We should trust public school teachers and we should support age appropriate sex education in each Member State. We should support equal rights for women, for LGBTI and for all young people who want to live in freedom. The Polish government is creating fear. It is the worst thing you can do to young people when you are creating fear and when they can’t live in freedom about love or their sexuality. Worst affected will be young women and queer people in Poland. Young women should learn about their rights from a young age. The Polish bill is a bill in a row of many initiatives discriminating young women and young queer people in Poland. For us the Greens, it is important to stand in solidarity with queer activists, with feminists in Poland and to say ‘you are not alone!’ You are right and you have us on your side. text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, you call this pedophilia and it is not. The Polish right wants to establish an educational model that restricts the sexual and reproductive rights of children and also violates the rights of women and the LGTBI collective.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago in Brussels, I met with a group of young girls as part of the Girls Speak Out week in the Parliament. I spoke to them about sexual education and consent in the countries they were from and the type of education they had received in school. Not one of them was able to say to me that they had received comprehensive sex education. We have a long way to go across the Union in relation to this. If we in Europe are to ensure gender equality – real equality – where women, girls, men and boys, understand their value, worth and responsibilities, we need to progress sexual education, not hamper it. We must educate our young people. As I know well from Ireland, it is rather a lack of education, as opposed to education, that results in alarming and unexpected consequences. And what consequences they are. Development of healthy relationships is hampered, awareness of what constitutes sexual abuse is stifled, and fundamentally it does a disservice to the youth in Europe by denying them the right of information, a fundamental of our democracy.  As regards the proposal that to teach young people about sexual education would be akin to promoting paedophilia, I say absolute nonsense. In fact, sexual education can heighten young people’s understanding and therefore make them more aware of what constitutes sexual abuse and protect them. To deny young people the opportunity of such an education makes them vulnerable, not just at that moment, but actually throughout their lives.  Fundamentally, this proposal will not, and cannot, achieve its true aim to reduce the numbers of young people engaging in sexual activity. Rather, we must encourage young people to be careful and responsible should they make a choice to do so. The only way to do that is through thorough and comprehensive sexual education. I would urge the Polish government not to progress in this manner and not to proceed in this manner.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, the Polish authorities' proposal to ban and criminalize sex education goes against the times. It encourages younger people to approach sexuality through channels and materials such as pornography, which are in the antipodes of the values that are supposed to be advocated by the promoters of that initiative. Experience shows that educating, teaching, applying the knowledge and experience of pedagogy to approaching a basic aspect of the human condition such as sexuality is a success, and opposing it, pretexting that talking normally about sex can enhance inconvenient behaviors, is incomprehensible.  That's why I want to vindicate those programs. In Navarra, a Spanish region, the most reactionary right also opposed a sex education program for schoolchildren; a programme that combated gender stereotypes and has been awarded by many international organizations, including Unesco. I'm asking for a reflection. We are talking about education, freedom, pedagogy, and we are in Europe. Penalizing such programs goes against history and especially against people.  (She refused to have Anna Zalewska ask her a question under the "blue card" procedure.)

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Commissioner King that this subject is not just about teaching, it’s about equality, dignity and children’s rights, which are fundamental rights and values of the EU contained within the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. One of the most fundamental duties of any society is to teach its youth about equality and healthy relationships. Healthy relationships means learning to respect each other and to treat each other with equality and dignity. We all share this duty as parents, educators and legislators – and the EU as well – to empower future generations to learn about themselves, their bodies, their rights and their autonomy.  To deny children’s right to knowledge and inhibit their own bodily autonomy would undermine and seriously restrict their rights. To criminalise the teaching of sexual health and education to under-18s is deeply alarming. It requires that children pay the price for regressive political views, which are not their own, at a cost of their health, well—being and fundamental rights. This bill targets LGBT+ and women’s rights in particular, as it violates Poland’s commitments to international agreements on women’s rights, the Istanbul Convention and CEDAW. name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on storms in Europe – particularly the heavy rains in Spain and of the hurricane in Azores (Portugal) (2019/2892(RSP)).

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission is obviously well aware of the impact of the storms and flooding in several regions in the south-east of Spain and of Hurricane Lorenzo on the Azores, and our sympathy goes to all those who were caught up in these violent weather events, who’ve lost their livelihoods and suffered damage.  The Commission is currently exploring, with the Spanish and with the Portuguese authorities, the best ways to support the recovery from the damage caused. The EU Solidarity Fund provides Member States and regions affected by serious natural disasters with financial assistance for emergency and recovery operations. The Commission services, in fact, have already had meetings with the authorities of the Valencia region and with the authorities of the Azores to explain the conditions and the procedures that activate the Solidarity Fund.  The Spanish Government in a recent letter to the Commission have announced their intention to apply for Solidarity Fund assistance once they’ve completed the ongoing damage assessment. If the applications are submitted within the deadline and their assessment by the Commission reveals that the conditions for activating the Solidarity Fund are met then the Commission will move rapidly to propose an amount of aid to be approved by this House and by the Council. In both cases, these would be categorised as so-called ‘regional disasters’, for which aid can amount to up to 2.5% of the total direct damage.  In addition, the European Structural and Investment Funds can intervene to help with certain recovery operations, and again, as some of the damage concerned affects the agricultural sector, the EU Rural Development Policy provides for restoring agricultural production potential damaged by natural disasters and catastrophic events and introduction of appropriate preventive actions, so it too could provide support to help farmers cope with the impact of natural disasters. And to compensate for damage caused to primary producers by heavy rains and floods, Member States can, as I’m sure you know, also consider granting state aid. So in these different ways that I have just set out, we stand ready to help those affected by these severe weather events.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for the House adopting this morning the inclusion on the agenda of such an important issue and that we can have this debate.  As the representative of the Commission commented, the Spanish Government argued that it was still calculating the damage suffered by Murcia, Valencia and Almería following the so-called 'cold drop', following the torrential rains in Spain between 12 and 15 September. These damages are already calculated, and what I want to report to this House is the passivity of the Spanish government – the Government of Pedro Sánchez – in activating and implementing the Solidarity Fund as quickly as possible; in the case of Murcia in particular, this region meets all the requirements to be a beneficiary of the Solidarity Fund.  We are talking about the fact that unfortunately there have been six fatalities and damages that are already calculated by the regional government of Murcia at EUR 560 million in this region. In Valencia and Andalusia the damage is estimated at 190 million euros. We are talking about damage that has already been accounted for and of citizens who are waiting for Europe to react.  One of the main European values is solidarity and the European Solidarity Fund is to work in cases like these, to react and respond to citizens who are overwhelmed and in often dramatic situations like the ones we are currently experiencing.  Therefore, from here, from the European Parliament, I call on the Council, I ask the Member States to speed up as much as possible the launch of the European Solidarity Fund. And I say this in the face of a threat that there may be torrential rains affecting the Balearic Islands, Valencia or Catalonia these days.  The European Union has to react quickly and cannot be an agency that takes weeks and weeks to react to natural disasters such as those we have just suffered in Spain or those suffered by our neighbours in Portugal , in the Azores.  Europe must be able to be supportive and must be able to react quickly to the need of citizens.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I welcome the fact that this debate may take place, but I am very sorry for the unwelcome intervention by the representative of the Group of the European People's Party, because I believe that it is misrewhere that the floods and the terrible consequences that have occurred are used for partisan purposes because Spain is facing elections on 10 November.  All administrations are doing their job: the regional ones, the local ones, the Government of Spain , which has already estimated an initial assessment, and we must wait to know the result of all the damage that has been caused in order to make a correct estimate.  And I would like to point out that it is climate change, fundamentally, that is responsible for the phenomenon known as 'the cold drop', which devastatingly affects eastern Spain, the Mediterranean regions — Catalonia, the Balearic Islands, Murcia, Almeria; to my region, the Valencian Community, but also to the inland regions — La Rioja, Navarra and Madrid; it is the result of climate change that we all have a responsibility to combat.  Now what we are asking for is the need to act together so that all resources and instruments, of course also those of the European Union, are put at the service of citizens. It is the citizens who have to feel that their institutions are at their side when they need them most, to recover everything they have lost, and certainly to invest - and for that I appeal to the need for European funds – so that this never happens again.  Because it occurs too often: it cannot be that in the Mediterranean we suffer drought, we have the consequences of desertification and, at the same time, these rainy phenomena that prevent water from being used to combat drought and end up getting lost at sea. It is time to prioritize investment so that we never suffer from situations like this again, and that the alerts that occur tonight, even in the regions that were devastated, do not have these consequences again in the future.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, last September, southeastern Spain suffered one of the worst storms of the last 140 years, with torrential rains reaching 450 litres per square meter.  The consequences have been devastating: we are talking about six dead, more than four thousand evacuated, many people who have become homeless, roads cut off and infrastructure damage in more than twenty-five municipalities. But this area is the orchard of Spain, the orchard of Europe, and to this we must add the significant damage to more than three thousand hectares of cultivation and losses of more than 500 million in agriculture.  And I would also like to recall the serious impact it has had on the Lesser Sea, a unique ecosystem of great environmental interest, whose preservation was already complicated and which has been further aggravated by this flood. So we have important environmental and economic consequences in this area as well.  In the face of this serious situation, what we are asking is that the Solidarity Fund be launched. We need to deal with the havoc caused by the cold drop and restore hope to all those families who have lost their homes, farmers and fishermen, and help them rebuild their lives and their future.  Because DANA is yet another example of the natural disasters that will affect Europe in the coming years as a result of climate change and highlights the need for all Member States to combat climate change together, because just as it has affected Spain and Portugal it will also affect other European regions.  Unfortunately, it's not a problem that's going to go away. Today in Spain, for example, we have been alert to a new storm coming. European mechanisms, such as the European Union Solidarity Fund, need to respond to these problems.  But we also need to bet on scientific research that helps prevent natural disasters and helps reduce the strong impact it has on people's lives, the economy and the environment.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, we express our closeness to the families of the victims and to the populations affected by this tragedy, which has certainly affected Spain, Portugal and other regions of our continent.  Only a year ago, I would remind you, Storm Vaia caused more than EUR 6 billion in damage in Italy and millions of trees felled, and then the European Union recognised EUR 247 million from the Solidarity Fund.  We cannot fail to recognise that there is an important climate change taking place that is increasingly generating intense and extreme weather events. And then we cannot fail to point out that this climate change is partly conditioned by the anthropological development of global warming and therefore by pollution.  The commitments made by the future European Commission, the Member States and this Parliament on the Green Deal we trust can be put into practice as soon as possible and can, above all, generate the expected results. But for the first expected results, which then also have an effect on the climatic effects, it will perhaps take decades. In the meantime, extreme phenomena will continue and perhaps even more intense than at present. And to aggravate the situation there are also the high hydrogeological risk to which some areas are subjected, the lack of maintenance and cementification. After the grief, we are thinking of the damage and therefore of the extraordinary and solidarity funds, which are right, but they cannot be enough. It is indeed necessary for the Member States, with the support of the Union, to develop wide-ranging projects, encouraging the reconstruction of natural habitats in favour of cementification and to strengthen the banks of rivers and to fight where abuse exists, which then clearly turns, as in this case, into tragedy. A real hydrogeological safeguard plan to face what, unfortunately, for the next few decades will no longer be extraordinary events.

text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are talking about floods and their consequences. It is cynical to hear the Spanish People's Party, whose leader recently ridiculed our country by ignoring and belittling climate change; a party that has been systematically collaborating on irresponsible constructions, based on ball and corruption, in flood zones, areas that now suffer from floods. The absolute opacity of hydrographic confederations has been sustained. This has to change.  Directive 2007/60/EC on flood risk assessment and management recognises climate change as one of the factors contributing to increasing the frequency of floods. Despite this, the European Commission is not taking the necessary measures. They need to stop paying the same. That is why, on the one hand, it is important that the Solidarity Fund of the European Union , which was set up to intervene in the event of serious natural disasters , bring solidarity to regions in Spain such as Navarra, the Balearic Islands or The Valenci Country, and on the other hand, we already need courageous measures and governments that enforce a just transition, a new model, and that stop speculating and marketing with basic resources such as water.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Mr President, on 2 October, a hurricane in the Azores, an outermost region, caused more than EUR 330 million of damage. The Azores are composed of nine islands. On one of the islands, Flores Island, the Port of The Sea, which is even vital to securing essential goods, has been destroyed, a loss of about EUR 190 million. Portugal has more than €13 billion to be executed in Portugal 2020. There is no shortage of resources to meet the needs of this region, to also meet people who have suffered high losses. And we must never forget that we are talking about an outermost region that needs additional support for an exceptional situation.

text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I brought you this in my speech in this Parliament two weeks ago, a few days after Hurricane Lorenzo passed through the Azores archipelago.  At that time, the destruction sway on several islands was clearly visible and the high damage resulting from this phenomenon was already being guessed. Today we know that public and private losses exceed EUR 330 million, a sum which has a particularly heavy meaning for a small region of dual insularity and outermost. We also know that these losses have affected across society, from housing to commerce and services, port infrastructure and vessels, farms and agricultural crops. I welcome here the efforts at regional level, both in preventing the prevention that has prevented major damage and in the measures already in place to support the affected populations, but I return once again to ask for support to ensure effective European solidarity with the Azores, a support which must be, I say again, real, fast efficient.
