name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the passage of Hurricane Lorenzo through the Azores has caused significant destruction and major damage, destruction of homes, several displaced persons, destruction of infrastructure, telecommunications, energy and others, destruction of a commercial port essential for the supply of fuel and food to the islands of Flores and Corvo. In the face of the disaster, aid must be given to those affected, particularly those who have been displaced, in addition to the necessary restoration of the infrastructure affected, which will certainly require the mobilisation of hundreds of millions of euros. This support should be mobilised as promptly as possible. Moreover, this is also the time for us to undertake a reflection on the adequacy of the European Union's instruments, particularly in budgetary matters, to deal with these types of situations.  We think there is a need and there is room for improvement. In addition to the Solidarity Fund, which has been refined in the past and which can still be improved, the answer cannot be left by the reprogramming of Structural Funds. It's just that they need to be missed and to cover a place we're going to take it out of the others. So the answer has to go beyond that. For exceptional and unforeseen situations we must provide for exceptional support.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, I would like to start with expressing my sincere condolences and sympathies to those families who lost their loved ones in the floods in southern Spain. I know the Solidarity Fund is not a rapid response instrument, I know that, but I believe that there is a lot of room to improve its response time. I know that a lot has been invested in efforts to improve the way the Fund is functioning and the time it needs to send help to the regions that are affected by floods or other natural disasters, but I believe solidarity is solidarity when it is in time. Help is help when it’s in time.  So, there is – I think – a lot still to be done, and I think the current European Commissioner and the next European Commissioner could work on that. I believe Cohesion Policy could be designed in order to help in such cases but in a balanced manner, because endless reprogramming of operational programmes could put in danger our strategic goals. So the Solidarity Fund could work much better and I think this Parliament could contribute to the further improvement of the Fund in order to help citizens.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, over time the European Union has shown strong signs of solidarity with the different Member States and several would be the cases that could be listed here, but I will focus on what really matters, people. During the passage of Hurricane Lorenzo in the Azores, an outermost region, on October 2 this year, about 255 occurrences were recorded and 53 people had to be rehoused. The passage of this hurricane caused the total destruction of the Port of Lajes nas Flores, which put at risk the supply to the western group of the Azores archipelago. According to what was announced by the Regional Government of the Azores, it is estimated that the hurricane caused damage totaling 330 million euros. Mr President, I call once again for the European Commission to demonstrate that we are stronger together. It is time to show that we are governing for people and that we are attentive to their needs. In this sense, I call for a rapid mobilisation of the Solidarity Fund and for the funds to be rescheduled to help the people of the Azores cope with the enormous damage.

name: Álvaro AMARO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we have all spoken here in solidarity, in this case with Spain and the Autonomous Region of the Azores, an outermost region, and this word of solidarity, we all think it is a very expensive word in all European policies. Well, we just heard the Commissioner list us of a number of perspectives from which solidarity can be put into practice. I sincerely believe that, as has already been mentioned, isabel and José Manuel Fernandes have just said it and others, what is at stake here is not only the cast of hypotheses, it is to put these hypotheses on the ground. And what I see is that there are, in some cases or in some situations, the surveys made, in others not even that, but the populations and businesses and people, as mentioned, people who unfortunately disappeared, bereaved families, but people also displaced, without goods, without equipment, with economic life destroyed. And if there is a time when this solidarity fund, in good time created and adjusted, in addition to the other mechanisms, but aimed at being placed on the ground at the right time.  The President of the Portuguese said yesterday that this matter can never fall by the wayside. For us, it will not fall by the wayside and that is the appeal we make to the Commission.

name: Adriana MALDONADO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, I would like, first of all, to tell the lady of the People's Party what there are things that are not played with. And you don't play with the damage of families who have suffered the floods in these months in Spain. And you don't play with the damage of traders who have been having to clean up the mud of their shops and who still can't open them.  And I am talking not only about the cases of Valencia, Murcia, the Balearic Islands, Castile and León or Castilla-La Mancha. I am also talking about a small community such as Navarra, of only 600,000 inhabitants, but that in July we saw how on the streets of its middle area, especially in Tafalla and in more than twenty-two locations, there was not only one deceased — that is, the life of a person who has been lost – but also many shops affected , like many households of many families who, today, are still not able to go home.  We are therefore talking about a momentous change that the European Union has to adopt. With climate change we have seen that we have gone behind in the politics of the new future, and we have to take into account one thing: we have to give answers.  Because of course the Government of Spain has been there, as our councillors, our mayors and all the neighbors of our peoples have been. But the European Union also has to give answers.  And that is why it is very important that the Solidarity Fund is a change, that it be updated and that new mechanisms are created from the European Union to provide answers and help all our citizens.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: – Mr President, hurricane Lorenzo, when it hit the Azores, caused enormous material damage, but we must point out that there was fortunately no personal injury. This is a merit of the Civil Protection action of the Regional Government of the Azores and the enormous awareness of the Azoreans when they are faced with a hurricane of that intensity.  In the material damage, the most serious situation, has already been said, is that which concerns the Port of Lajes das Flores, whose operation depends on the supply of the two islands, the populations of Flores and Corvo for all kinds of essential goods. This requires a quick response, which is why the Portuguese Members of the S&D Group addressed a question to the European Commission on 3 October. For the Members of the S&D Group did not wake up to this theme twenty days later for a reason of internal partisan guerrilla.  We understand that we all have to be united to find answers to people's problems. These responses go through the Solidarity Fund, but, Commissioner, there is no 2.5% support for 330 million damages. More, much more European solidarity is needed for the Azoreans and we will be here to remind you that this has to be met with a response from the European Union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am not from Either Spain or Portugal, but I have come forward precisely because I know that the impact of climate change and extreme droughts and extreme floods, so we are exposed to this across the European Union, not only by the European Union, but by all continents, is a matter for all political parties.  None of the political parties should take credit for this, but I am glad that we are discussing this here, and it turns out that the Solidarity Fund should work more efficiently, faster, it is certainly a task for the new European Commission, which must take action on this matter, as colleagues are calling for and demanding here.  But I think prevention is always preferable. Prevention is always cheaper and more effective, which is why I agree that the European Union is a leader in the fight against climate change and must force those global players, as well as use cohesion funds, forest plantings and other measures that can mitigate or eliminate some of the effects of extreme fluctuations.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, until then, I find that this European Solidarity Fund is like a dressing slowly placed over a serious wound. I call on the European Commission to find a solution for this solidarity fund to become what it should be: an emergency treatment for those people who need emergency assistance at European level, because yes, indeed, these things are happening and, unfortunately, we see that we cannot live under a glass bell that will protect us at all times. Instead, we can prevent such things.  I remind you that the cutting of forests in Europe has led to real dramas and that we have tabled in the Romanian Parliament the Ciuhodaru law which provides for the prohibition of forest cuttings and their use for export, and only to be able to be in the form of processed wood.  On the other hand, there is talk of human casualties, and here the European Commission must have a major role. That European civil protection mechanism, that European SMURD should be functional because in such a situation of collective accident, of an emergency, we should have the resources to treat our European citizens where it is needed, when needed, and to call for solidarity, which is extremely important.  Thirdly, also in the idea of prevention, think about this: it comes down to terrible situations because we did not prevent it, and yes, it could be these things prevented if the agricultural subsidy, (the President interrupted the speaker)... note, the agricultural subsidy would be the same at European level, including for farmers in Romania.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The debate is closed.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: The next item is the one—minute speeches on matters of political importance (Rule 172).

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European In Romania, after the adoption of the motion of censure and the replacement of the left-wing ruling coalition, the best chance is for a transitional government established by the right. The task of the new Cabinet is to pursue a strict fiscal policy until the parliamentary elections, to ensure the functioning of the municipalities, to reallod usable EU funds, to launch large investments and to prepare fair elections.  The presentation of next year's budget will not be delayed. Corrections will be needed in the economy, as the Commission calculates that for the period 2017-2020 the Government of Bucharest has borrowed more than in the years of the economic crisis. In a reasonable governance that is useful for the country as a whole, the RMDSZ, the representative of Hungarians in Romania, will be a partner. After next year's parliamentary elections, priority issues such as education, the environment, health and a healthy lifestyle must be addressed. There is a need to build trust between the Romanian majority and the Hungarian minority, and to start a dialogue on interethnic relations. Work needs to be made on a project in a country that is liveable and developing for all. Thank you.

name: César LUENA
text: – Mr. President, President Mitterrand said that nationalism is war. Protectionism is trade war. And in those we are, because since last Friday we have tariffs for many products. Look, the Spanish agri-food sector is very affected. It is the eighth most important in the world, and cheese, oil and table olives, and wine, will be affected by these unfair tariffs.  I don't think the road is any more war, and I tell the European Commission that putting tariffs may not be the solution. The solution is dialogue. A dialogued solution must be found so that there is no trade war that, according to the International Monetary Fund, can affect an entire generation.  And in the meantime, you help. I ask the European Commission to compensate the wine sector, which is one of the most affected , with aid and to make an additional system of promotion for wine, because it will need it. Dear colleagues, trade warfare is not the solution. The solution is dialogue, compensation and aid.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, the Catalan crisis is not a matter of public order: there is a total rejection of violence there. That is why it will not be settled with sentences, let alone if the right of expression is threatened or parliamentary inviolability is ignored. This is a political issue that is blocking and needs to create new spaces for dialogue and solution.  In democracy, nothing is possible without law, but the law cannot be the frontier to prevent an essential debate. That blocks the situation today.  I therefore encourage the Union to help 'reset' the Catalan crisis, which is a European problem. Not for nothing, the Union is a specialist in uniting diversity and is well aware that commitment requires involvement, dialogue, empathy, mutual recognition and civic and political courage, values that defuse those who think more about short-term performance than problem-solving.

name: Anna CAVAZZINI
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the This sweater I have on today is fair trade – fair fashion. I had to go to a special store and look at exactly what label what it means to buy a piece of clothing that is free of child labour and exploitation. That cannot be the case, this is a perverse world! It should be the other way around: all the products we wear must be free from exploitation and child labour from the outset. All products that can be bought in the EU must be free from pollution and deforestation from the outset. Volunteering in an opaque label jungle will not get any further. We are in 2019, and we have a few years left to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. We now need a law that makes human rights and environmental standards binding along the entire supply chain. The global race for the lowest standards must end. Let us work together to ensure that the EU finally has a supply chain law!

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on 12 October, the leader of Syria's Future Party, Hevrin Kalaf, thirty-five years old, was murdered in an ambush and her body was offended by her cowardly murderers, who spread the images around the world as a warning to all women who do not want to lower their eyes. Hevrin Kalaf had a degree in civil engineering and devoted her entire short life to claiming women's rights, but above all to working for peaceful coexistence between Kurds, Christian-Syrians and Arabs, evidently too many merits for a woman. His weapons, which are dialogue and courage, have annoyed the criminal forces in Syria who want to restore a fanatical and murderous Islamic state.  Europe cannot remain the cause of this horror, we must immediately block all funding from Ankara and block any possibility of Turkey joining the European Union. Let us stop the genocide of the Kurdish people and the annihilation of the only army that has fought Islamic terrorism, hand in hand. An army in which many women like Hevrin are active, who, with their men, have been so far and, let us not forget, the only bulwark against the return of Islamic terrorists to Europe.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: Mr President, no, they are not taking it easy on the beaches of the Costa Brava. If you have not seen them for five months, it is because they are not allowed to sit. Who are we talking about? We are talking about our three Catalan colleagues, who were democratically elected like all of us here on 26 May, but who have never been able to put a single foot in this Chamber. What are they being blamed for? They are accused of holding a referendum. They didn't kill anyone, they held a referendum.  So, honestly, as a French elected official on the merits of the case, whether Or not Catalonia is independent, that is not my problem. My problem, our problem, is the instrumentalization of justice for political purposes. If we let this pass today, there is nothing to tell us that it will not set a precedent and that tomorrow others will not take the opportunity to declare that a particular member of an opposition party does not have the right to sit in the European Parliament.  I'm asking you to react. Again, it is not a question of us deciding whether catalonia should be independent or not, it is about defending political freedoms. It is about defending democracy. This is a European problem, and this guilty silence of the European Union cannot last any longer.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: - Dear Chairman, freedom of movement is one of the greatest achievements of the European Union. In order for Croatian citizens to use this achievement, Croatia has ensured the full application of the Schengen acquis in the past two years. Today, over six and a half thousand Croatian police officers guard the longest land border of the European Union. Croatia's accession to Schengen will ensure better transport links, economic co-operation, but also the protection of common external borders. Therefore, this is in the interest not only of Croatia, but also of all other Member States, but also of the European Union as a whole.  That is why it is right that the European Commission decides on Croatia's technical readiness to join the Schengen area solely and solely on the basis of objective assessment, while rejecting unsubjudged political pressures. Croatia is ready for Schengen.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the future of Europe is the great issue of this parliamentary term, without a doubt, for the European Parliament. Ten years ago the Lisbon Treaty came into force, but from that moment on, different transformations and events have taken place: to begin, of course, the fact of Brexit, the crisis of managing migration flows, the consequences of the economic and financial crisis. All of this forces us to keep up with our policies and our institutions.  That is why I believe that we must begin the debate on this future of Europe, which in my opinion has to be that of a political union of federal court, that is, a political union where national vetoes do not exist, nor blockades in the Council, and where Parliament can co-decide on an equal footing with the Council in all matters , including taxation, own resources and the multiannual budget.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Mr President, in my home country, Slovakia, these days people are hearing really shocking information about the links between organised crime, the courts, the prosecution service and politics. Every day, the testimonies of the recordings obtained during the investigation into the murder of Ján Kuciak are leaked to the public, and from them a picture of a kidnapped state is leaked, where justice can indeed be bought and, in fact, quite cheaply, directly at the Prosecutor General's Office or in the Supreme Court. It also turns out that for years, government politicians have covered up these things and guaranteed impunity to the actors of these spells. This has only changed now in recent months, thanks to the courage of investigators and journalists, and also to public pressure and civil protests. It goes without saying that all these cases need to be thoroughly investigated. And that is not the role of the European Union. The fight for a fair and fair society must be won by Slovakia on its own. However, the failure of justice in one Member State of the European Union is a problem for the whole of the European Union, because without mutual trust, neither the free market nor any other policies can function. That is why it is also something that the European Union must address.

name: Magid MAGID
text: – Mr President, friends, as-salamu alaykum. I don’t care where you place yourself on the ideological spectrum. I don’t care how you came into power or why you came into power. If you have any influence in any sense, to be in politics in the 21st century is to be in the collective war room of humanity against environmental catastrophe. So let me say this as clearly as possible: climate justice is empty without social justice. The front lines are in the marginalised edges of global power. It is the poor, the more vulnerable, those beyond the easy embrace of development who will pay the catastrophic consequences of a world spinning its way into oblivion.  So I salute those who are shaking us. I salute the climate strikers skipping school to save school, the Extinction Rebels disrupting indifference, and the countless young activists like Isra Hirsi and Xiye Bastida who are proving no one is ever too small to make a difference. But most important of all, I salute the countless unnamed activists of the Global South, fighting for their way of life in the face of the consequences of corporate greed. Our victory is a victory of humanity and we must be diverse in voices, strategies and actions, and we must act now.

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Mr President, while we are only finishing with five long years of a Juncker Commission, which has been a disaster for the people in every respect, the new Von der Leyen Commission is already under the sign of continuity.  The rejection of Sylvie Goulard, the French candidate for the post of European Commissioner, endorsed by President Macron, is a salutary democratic outburst. His collusion with US lobbyists, as well as the large remunerations paid to him during his tenure as an MEP, cast doubt on his independence and the absence of any conflict of interest.  The von der Leyen team promises to be a caricature of the worst of the European Union. Having recycled the socialists and ultra-liberals of the previous mandate, the President's close guard is now seeking to impose German officials everywhere in order to control all cabinets. The current European Union is the antithesis of an alliance that benefits all. It shows the face of a vast machinery serving German interests.  It would be wise for the next European Council to put the European treaties on the table and give back to the European nations their essential prerogatives at a time when peoples are awakened and a tremendous thirst for democracy.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, last week the British court ruled against Emma DeSouza’s Good Friday Agreement right to Irish citizenship. Emma and her husband, Jake, were dragged through the British court by the British Government, which failed to legislate on Irish citizenship 21 years after the Good Friday Agreement. Britain is a country which you cannot trust, a country that never keeps its word, Perfidious Albion. So, until MEPs see Brexit legislation enacted, we must not give our consent to the Withdrawal Agreement because the British establishment will be working to undercut it piece by piece. Last week, it wasn’t just Emma who lost her case. We all lost. As an Irish and EU citizen, Emma has the right to love and to sponsor her husband, Jake, and she has the right to defend Irish citizenship. Britain needs to upgrade its archaic 1981 citizenship legislation to fulfil its Good Friday Agreement obligations. Otherwise, British citizens could lose their British citizenship in a united Ireland just as our Irish citizenship is denied to us now, and we don’t want to see that happen.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: Mr President, in 2015 Greece took on the greatest burden of the migration problem. The 2016 European Union-Turkey declaration worked, but for several months now, hundreds of refugees and migrants have been arriving daily on the islands of the north-eastern Aegean and the situation is explosive. A huge rally tonight was held in Samos by desperate civilians. At the same time, President Erdoğan is blackmailing new uncontrolled flows.  In this very difficult situation, Greece is unable on its own to manage the problem, despite the migration policy of the new government that respects international law and human rights. We cannot, ladies and gentlemen, proceed like this. We must all share responsibility for the problem, which is European, here and now. Countries that have closed their borders urgently need to accept their own refugees. The solution and management of the matter must be immediate, proportionate, in solidarity, but above all fair.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, in 2016, after the so-called 'coup d'état', I would call it a 'fake coup' in Turkey, I stressed from here, anxiously, this: every day that passes with Erdogan in power, the human cost that will be paid inside and outside Turkey to rid us of this beast accumulates. Since then there has been a lot of terrible things going on inside Turkey and now we are facing a new crime against the Kurds.  It is not just a matter of betraying our allies against the scourge of the Islamic State, it is not just a matter of security or credibility. The problem is that we have before us the Neo-Ottoman expansionist policy that Erdogan commits with crimes against humanity. So we have a criminal who heralds a national clean-up and illegal movement of populations, just as Turkey imposed on Cyprus in 1974 and the crime continues. It is time to bring the criminal before the International Criminal Court in The Hague.

name: Chris DAVIES
text: – Mr President, I have heard the European Union described in Britain as an empire, a malevolent force out to control and constraint. After 15 years in this Parliament, I know that the European Union has many faults, but a malevolent empire it is not. It is a partnership that allows governments to address issues that no one country can tackle alone. It is a champion of freedom and democracy. It is proof, in a world where superpowers can impose their will on small nations, that we are better together. In a continent that has seen centuries of conflict, it embodies the conviction that this must never happen again.  A Brexit deal has been agreed between the European Council and Boris Johnson. But my voters don’t want this deal. They don’t want any deal. They want to remain European citizens and for Britain to be a leader in Europe, not a leaver. We should do all we can to resist Brexit. But if we win or if we lose, whatever, we call upon our colleagues here to build upon the strength of this European Union and live up to its aspirations to be a force for good in the world.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Mr President, this morning in Riga, in front of the Lithuanian Embassy, we demonstrated our solidarity with the political prisoner Algirdas Paleckis, one of the most outstanding anti—fascist activists in Lithuania and a former Member of Parliament, who has been in prison for one year. Algirdas is being persecuted for his opinion dissenting from the official one on some events in the modern history of Lithuania, namely in January 1991. Political prisoners in the European Union include: in the Baltic Sea, Algirdas Paleckis, as well as a number of other Lithuanian and Latvian people; in the Mediterranean, my former colleagues, MEPs Oriol Junqueras and Raul Romeva, as well as a number of other Catalan people. Political prisoners in the European Union – in the European Union, which is teaching the whole world how to respect human rights. Liberating Algirdas, Oriol, Raul and all the other political prisoners would be a good start for the European Union towards respect for political freedoms.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Italy, the national media have portrayed the Malta Summit on Migrants on 23 September as an important step towards the redistribution of migrants in Europe. What happened to the Malta Agreement of 23 September? Nothing but a ridiculous staging from which the Member States have gradually paraded, as demonstrated by what happened at the last summit of European Interior Ministers. In my view, what matters is not to redistribute migrants, but not to get them there. The policy of "common evil half gaudio" does not belong to us. Redistributing migrants without any control means redistributing potential terrorists as well. There are one billion and two hundred million people in Africa, how can we expect to redistribute all those who would like to come to Europe?  Europe has a duty to defend its borders. It owes it to its culture, its Christian roots and its own system of values. The Malta Summit should have tried to help the countries with the most exposed borders to the waves of migration and to close the ports and patrol the borders, as our Interior Minister Matteo Salvini taught the whole of Europe.

name: Peter POLLÁK
text: – Mr President, my speech today will not speak for the benefit of my home country. However, I have to say what is happening in Slovakia. We had a feeling that there was both corruption and poor law enforcement in Slovakia. However, what the last few days have shown us has shocked us. Slovakia is facing a corruption case of Gorilla, which has been unex examined for seven years. Politicians even say it doesn't exist. However, the public has heard a recording of the vault suspected of ordering the murder of Martina and Ján Kuciak. He also found a recording in which he is in a relationship with the former attorney general to whom he swears and influences the investigation. The atrocities on Kocher's phone show that the decisions of judges and state authorities were handled for bribes. We all heard it, but no one was hurt. Judges, prosecutors and politicians stayed in their seats, and there was no charges. Today, there is no doubt that what is happening and happening in Slovakia is directly related to the murder of John and Martina. Corrupt police officers, prosecutors and judges cannot stay in their seats. I ask all those involved here in Strasbourg and Brussels, let us do everything we can to cleanse our Slovakia together.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: – Mr President, in July 2017, after a long work of the S&D group, the European Parliament adopted a resolution call on the European Commission to organise an action plan on HIV-AIDS infection, viral hepatitis and tuberculosis. The previous action plan had ended at the end of 2016 and this was followed by a prolonged silence that lasts to this day. The truth is that it is a grave mistake to devalue this epidemic. There are more than 800,000 Europeans living with HIV infection. 120, 000 of them don't know they're carriers of the virus. Year after year there are 25,000 new diagnosed cases and this number has not decreased. To combat the HIV-AIDS epidemic we need to keep this issue at the heart of political attention and we need an appropriate strategy on the part of the European Union. Giving up is a very serious mistake and the European Parliament, on behalf of the citizens of Europe, has an obligation to urge the new European Commission to resume an action plan on this matter.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Mr President, Liviu Pop, a ranger from Romania, was killed the other day while defending the forest from wood thieves. In recent years, five other rangers have died: Răducu Gorcioia, Ieronim Oul, Dănel Boboc, Victor Chiriță, Gheorghe Dogaru. The European Commission released a report this year saying Romania is making progress in the fight against illegal logging. In the documents, the situation seems under control, of course, but the reality is quite different. A Recorder report reveals how a pyramid system made up of politicians, control authorities, private individuals makes 33% of Tree cuttings in Romania, in fact, illegal.  It is natural to ask ourselves, then: what is the European Commission missing? Romania's forests are protected in acts, but they are protected with blood, the blood of some people, in practice. As for those who are no longer with us, I want to tell their families, from this rostrum, that they are heroes of a fierce struggle between money and our right to nature and life.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Mr. Vice President, rare diseases are one of the big problems for health systems today. Given the high costs they mean for Member States, they represent a huge financial and organisational burden, especially for small countries such as the Republic of Croatia.  We have situations where simply a relatively small number of patients very often do not allow for the maintenance and financing of expensive hospital and other health resources, and this leads to a disparity between the level of health care for these patients relative to others.  What can the European Union do? Unfortunately, the European Union has relatively little competence in the field of health, as set out in Article 168 TSR. treaty on the functioning of the European Union and the application of competences in the Member States. However, this must not be an excuse and there must be no justification for doing nothing about it.  The fact is that the political climate has changed, the fact is that it is my political grouping that is the European People's Party that has elevated the issue of health to the level of high priority of the European Union itself, and I think that in this sense we should all try to make the maximum effort to define at European level an action plan and strategy for the fight against rare diseases.  Let's show that the European Union is not some bureaucratic super-creation, that it is not for its own purpose, let's help our patients, help the citizens of the European Union!

name: Ivo HRISTOV
text: – Dear Mr President, honourable Members, the Bulgarian justice system has been monitored for more than a decade. With him, my compatriots connected their hopes for establishing law and justice. Today, those hopes are dead. The amorphous formulations of the reports and their involuntary recommendations did not have a healing effect. The mechanism has proven ineffective and the problems in justice have deepened. The new monitoring report is yet to be released. I have no doubt that it will be another "gift" to the government in the run-up to the local elections. In recent years, the European Commission has not only defied monitoring, but turned it into a tool for political interference and vicious support of its favorites in Sofia. This discredits the Very European idea in the eyes of the Bulgarian citizens. A testament to their disappointment is the low turnout in the last European elections.  In conclusion, I would like to say that the failure of the verification and cooperation mechanism, which will be presented to us as a success, cannot deceive The Bulgarians, whose expectations of legality and fairness with European assistance have remained unfulfilled.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we will address the subject of the Turkish army's invasion of Syria on a special point. But at this point, I wanted to speak out to remind you that this year is exactly 70 years since we commemorated the signing of the Washington Treaty and the completion of transatlantic relations. This partnership has always been a great certainty and alliance between Europe and the US. And what we are witnessing today is of great concern to me. The erratic nature of the administration, and President Trump in particular, meant that the Kurds on the Syrian side were actually left unattended, and the European Union was not informed of this. It is clear that the new Trump administration does not seem to care so much about good cooperation with Europe. I think that's very shortsighted. Strengthening Euro-Atlantic relations is in favour of both partners.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: That concludes the item.
